name: Defending Democracy: How Cities Rise Up When Feds Push Down

contributors.name: Kendra Brooks
contributors.title: Minority Leader, Councilmember at Large
contributors.details: Kendra Brooks is the Minority Leader of Philadelphia City Council. She is a Councilmember At-Large from North Philadelphia and the first Working Families Party member ever elected to City Council. She has a background in organizing for social movements, public school advocacy, gun violence prevention, and restorative justice, all of which inform her priorities as an elected official. Some of her recent accomplishments include the POWER Act, which grants new rights and protections to low-wage workers; the nationally acclaimed Eviction Diversion Program and the end of for-profit evictions in Philadelphia; the Reproductive Freedom Task Force and historic funding for reproductive healthcare providers; expanding mobile crisis teams for mental and behavioral health; and protecting neighborhood-led community gardens.

contributors.name: Francesca Menes
contributors.title: Managing Director, Membership & Organizing
contributors.details: Francesca Menes, is the Managing Director, Membership & Organizing at Local Progress and Local Progress Impact Lab which works collectively to advance a racial and economic justice agenda through all levels of local government. Francesca is a political educator, legislative and policy strategist, entrepreneur and former television host committed to creating spaces to educate, inform and engage our people on the issues that are important in their daily lives; helping them to understand the personal is political and democratizing knowledge. She is the daughter of working-class Haitian immigrants raised in Miami’s Little Haiti community. With more than 15 years of experience, Francesca has led successful coalitions, legislative, policy and advocacy campaigns with undocumented families, immigrants, refugees, students, Black and communities of color, resulting in the passage of local, state, federal resolutions, policies and laws on the issues of education, immigration, housing, wage protections and job security.

contributors.name: Eunisses Hernandez
contributors.title: City Councilmember
contributors.details: Eunisses Hernandez is a community organizer, a daughter of Mexican immigrants, and a lifelong District 1 resident. Born and raised in Highland Park, she led campaigns, coalitions, and commissions that transformed local and statewide policy before running for City Council in 2021. Since taking office in December 2022, Councilmember Hernandez has prioritized a Care First agenda that focuses on investing in community care, workforce development, social services, and harm-reduction programs that help make our neighborhoods safer and healthier places for all Angelenos.

contributors.name: Vanessa Fuentes
contributors.title: Mayor Pro Tem, Austin City Council, District 2
contributors.details: Mayor Pro Tem Vanessa Fuentes represents District 2 on the Austin City Council, where she champions health equity, working families, and local democracy. As the daughter of an immigrant and a military veteran, she brings lived experience to her fight for inclusive, community-driven governance. Since 2021, she has led efforts to expand affordable housing, increase wages, and protect reproductive rights. Fuentes is a leading voice on resisting state and federal overreach, defending local control, civil rights, and the dignity of all people.

description: As federal authoritarianism threatens civil rights, immigration, and economic justice, cities are stepping up to defend democracy. Join District 2 Austin City Councilmember Vanessa Fuentes, former New York City Comptroller Brad Lander, and District 1 Los Angeles City Councilmember Eunisses Hernandez as they share diverse, frontline perspectives in this conversation moderated by Francesca Menes, Managing Director of the Membership & Organizing Team at Local Progress. If democracy survives this moment, it will be because cities held the line.

contributors.name: Helen Melluish
contributors.title: Vp Of Marketing, Vrbo
contributors.details: Helen Melluish is Vice President of Marketing at Vrbo, where she leads brand, and integrated marketing globally across one of the world’s largest vacation rental marketplaces.A seasoned marketing and operations executive, Helen has spent her career scaling consumer brands across e‑commerce, subscription, marketplace, and CPG. Before Vrbo, she served as Chief Operating Officer at Omaze, where she oversaw business development, marketing and product.Helen previously worked as a fractional CMO and Chief Growth Officer, partnering with companies including Juice Media, FlexFits, and MasterClass. Earlier in her career, she led global brand marketing at eHarmony, and held marketing and communications roles at eBay/Shopping.com

contributors.name: Neil Golson
contributors.title: VP, Brand & Creative
contributors.details: Neil F. Golson is VP of Brand & Creative at Realtor.com, where he leads consumer and B2B marketing, brand strategy, and high-profile campaigns shaping how Americans think about homeownership. A builder at heart, Neil has scaled brands and revenue across tech, real estate, energy, and retail—working with companies like Tesla, Home Depot, and Coca-Cola. He focuses on turning insight into systems that compound: connecting brand, product, data, and culture into durable advantage.

contributors.name: Kate Rush Sheehy
contributors.title: Co-Chief Strategist
contributors.details: Kate leads the strategy department at GSD&M and spends most of her time with the Corona, Southwest Airlines, and White Castle teams building First & Only brands. She joined GSD&M from Expedia Group where she led global brand strategy and advertising for Vrbo and launched the brand in 17 markets. Prior to that, she helped open R/GA Austin, where she led strategy, helped make Crocs cool again and launched Fossil into the wearables space. After college, Kate also spent time in Austin’s start-up world before getting back to using the Advertising degree she earned from the University of Texas at Austin.

contributors.name: Jennifer Bridie
contributors.title: VP of Marketing
contributors.details:
Jennifer is known for creating and leading dynamic Teams that drive Company growth and performance, and foster loyalty and engagement for one of the most beloved brands in the world. In her role, she is responsible for creating affinity and generating quality demand for the Southwest Brand and products with oversight of Customer acquisition strategy, media and sponsorship investments, and brand content and experiential. Prior to joining Southwest Airlines in 2013, she worked within the advertising industry, giving her a keen understanding of both the science and art that informs her perspective today.
 
She also gives back to her local community, volunteering with the National Charity League (NCL), Special Olympics of Texas, Feed My Starving Children, and other local organizations.

description: In a world where travel is unpredictable, housing is uncertain, and consumers are pulling back, how do brands that serve high-consideration decisions earn trust and love? This panel features leaders from Vrbo, Southwest Airlines, and Realtor.com — three brands navigating economic volatility, shifting expectations, and technological change while staying emotionally resonant. We'll explore how tech platforms build human connection, why emotional loyalty matters more than ever, and how creative strategies can evolve to meet the moment.

long_description: In 1979, David Greenberger, a recent art school grad became activities director at a Boston nursing home. David began interviewing the residents, rejecting pat questions with the unexpected: "Which do you prefer – coffee or meat?," “What is embarrassment?,” and “How close can you get to a penguin?” The result was The Duplex Planet, an early ‘zine characterized by humor, warmth and sincerity. Today David’s work takes the form of spoken word shows and recordings. Beyond the Duplex Planet explores notions of aging and its intersection with art and community. It’s also a slightly ironic look at the life of an artist devoted to documenting the elderly who is himself in his senior years.

contributors.name: Dario Russo
contributors.details: Dario Russo is an Australian writer/director working internationally across feature film and series. He created, co-wrote, and directed the viral web series "Italian Spiderman" and the cult television show "Danger 5". long_description: Nick (Jai Courtney), affable heir to a wealthy rural landowner, discovers his fiancée, Kori (Emily Browning), is cheating on him and wants nothing more than to just fix the problem. One night, he captures a rogue Fox (Olivia Colman), and she offers him a trade-off: if Nick lets her live, the Fox will help him save his relationship. All he has to do is push Kori into a magic hole with the power to change her into the perfect partner. Nick follows the Fox’s advice and the Kori who re-emerges seems to be everything he ever wanted. Until her strange new quirks make him question his decision.

Verdadero is tequila for quality enjoyment, meaningful moments, and living well.

long_description:
An offbeat comedy about friendship, purpose, and trying to grow something real in a city built to keep people apart.
Cory is a lonely, doomscrolling thirty-something whose most consistent relationship is with his Instagram algorithm. His apartment? An emotionally vacant, sterile, void. His fridge? Mostly Celsius. And his idea of connection is dodging calls from the one person who still tries: Fox, a soft-hearted, ex-con with terrible advice rooted in institutional paranoia and his love of films. 
Everything shifts when Cory has a run-in, literally, with Plantman, a rogue horticultural crusader armed with a mysterious dossier of negligent plant owners.
sort: PLANTMAN & BLONDIE: A DRESS UP GANG FILM

events.name: Dead Deer High

long_description: Sixty years & a million records ago, Robert Christgau invented Rock music criticism. Anyone who has ever read or written a Pop music review has been influenced by Christgau, who canonized legends from The Ramones to Public Enemy & infuriated icons from Lou Reed to Billy Joel. Now in his eighties, Bob is still at it—amazingly with the same vigor, wit, concision and craft that has defined his expansive career. But in a world where albums are irrelevant, where print is dead & where algorithms have eclipsed critics we are forced to ask: What happens next—for Bob, but also for all music criticism? Is this the end of something? Is Robert Christgau the last critic?

name: Power Ballad

contributors.name: John Carney
contributors.details: John Carney is an award-winning filmmaker, screenwriter, producer and former bass guitarist of the Irish band 'The Frames'. John's breakout feature 'Once' won numerous accolades, including an Academy Award for Best Original Song, and it was adapted for the stage, winning eight Tony Awards. He helmed 'Begin Again', Sing Street', and is the creator and showrunner of the anthology series 'Modern Love'. His recent feature ‘Flora and Son’ starring Joseph Gordon Levitt and Eve Hewson, premiered at Sundance and is now available on AppleTV+. John’s next film, ‘Power Ballad’, starring Paul Rudd and Nick Jonas, will be released in cinemas later this year.

long_description:
When Rick (Paul Rudd), a past-his-prime wedding singer, meets fading boy-band star Danny (Nick Jonas) during a gig, the two bond over music and a late-night jam session. But when Danny turns one of Rick’s songs into the hit that reignites his career, Rick sets out to reclaim the recognition he believes he deserves - even if it means risking everything he cares about. From writer-director John Carney (Sing Street, Once), POWER BALLAD is a feel-good story about music, self-respect, friendship, and the price of ambition. 

Lionsgate presents, in association with 30WEST + Fís Éireann / Screen Ireland, a Likely Story / Distressed Films production, in association with Treasure Entertainment.

long_description: The unsolved murder of Billy London, a gay adult film performer brutally killed in West Hollywood, was an urban legend for 33 years. A documentary intended to honor his life took an unexpected turn when members of the community joined forces to uncover overlooked clues, and seek a resolution to the mystery of who killed him. Drawing on a rare trove of VHS and personal footage, the film reveals a chilling overlap between the victim and some of the suspects who were captured on camera in films made in the narrow window of Billy's death.

name: Dead Deer High

contributors.name: Jo Rochelle
contributors.details: Jo Rochelle is a Jamaican-American screenwriter and filmmaker based in California, originally from Minneapolis. She attended New York University's Tisch School of the Arts as a Drama major, where she discovered her passion for writing and directing stories and hasn't stopped. She has written and directed award-winning short films and the feature film, “Jasmine is a Star” (streaming on FUSE+). Jo’s an alumnus of Teach for America where she taught 6th grade English and Social Studies in the Mississippi Delta. She was also a writer on seasons four and five of “Good Trouble” on Freeform/Hulu.

description: Designers make screens/flows for stakeholders to review, for users to test, and for many teams to adjust until everything matches the brand. But as AI acts on human intent directly, we’ll be designing for agents. Not users. Grounded in research, this talk explores the shift to Agentic Experience (AX), moving from crafting interfaces to orchestrating outcomes with zero visual affordances. Early-career designers will snap to this new reality, late-stage folks get to skip it, but mid-career Product people have the most to lose and need to redesign themselves for the AX era.

name: Own the Fan, Own the Future: Artists Building Loyalty

contributors.name: Alice Young
contributors.title: SVP, Global Fan Strategy
contributors.details: Alice Young is an experienced, forward-thinking executive with a tremendous track record of success in management, labels, and DSPs. In her decade-plus career in music she has distinguished herself as a fierce advocate for artists and a leader in global artist marketing.  After receiving her Masters from the Clive Davis Institute of Music at NYU, Alice began her career as Marketing Director at mtheory, where she led global campaigns for international superstars like Flume, Zac Brown Band, and Zedd, including the number one smashes "Stay" and "The Middle". Alice went on to work for the product team at Spotify, helping develop and market tools for artists and labels. Wanting to be closer to artists, she moved to her native Australia and took over as MD of Future Classic, one of the most culturally significant independent label brands in the world. In her capacity as MD she oversaw label, publishing and management operations for a roster of international acts including Flume, G Flip, and SOPHIE. At Virgin Music, Alice recently led the Grammy-winning campaign for St. Vincent, and oversees a team that runs marketing for artists including Clairo, Tove Lo, Tom Odell, and Sofi Tukker. It is in this capacity as an executive and leader where her experience truly shines through. She is currently focused on helping artists’ grow their owned audiences and cut through the noise in today’s marketplace.

description: In 2025, music campaigns live or die by fan connection, yet most artists don’t own their audience. Virgin Music Group’s Alice Young unpacks why taking control is more crucial than ever. From privacy-compliant data to personalized fan journeys, learn how to build long-term relationships beyond algorithms. Whether launching your first single or scaling globally, you’ll gain real tactics, tools, and creative strategies to turn passive followers into active superfans.

name: The Consumer’s Guide to Beating the Bots

contributors.name: Doha Mekki
contributors.title: Senior Fellow
contributors.details: Doha Mekki held the top roles in the U.S. Department of Justice’s Antitrust Division, serving until 2025 as the acting assistant attorney general — the agency’s top antitrust official. She served previously as principal deputy assistant attorney general, the division’s second-in-command, where she supervised all aspects of the Division’s work, including civil and criminal enforcement, litigation and trial, appeals, domestic and international policy, competition advocacy, and expert analysis programs. During her tenure, the division filed more monopolization cases than it had in nearly four decades. Mekki oversaw the investigation and litigation of landmark cases to stop criminal cartels, illegal mergers, and anticompetitive corporate practices in sectors across the U.S. economy.

contributors.name: Emily Stewart
contributors.title: Senior Correspondent
contributors.details: Emily Stewart is a senior correspondent on Business Insider’s Discourse team. She focuses on consumerism, culture, and the economy, among other topics. Some of her biggest stories have explored middle-class shoplifting, and convenience stores’ struggles. She also writes regularly about work, millennials, and economic trends. Emily appears regularly on nationally syndicated radio shows and podcasts, including Marketplace, The Weekend Dive, and Today, Explained. She has guest hosted C-SPAN’s “After Words” and moderated multiple panels on economic policy and workplace dynamics. Before joining Business Insider, Emily was at Vox, where she covered business and the economy and wrote a newsletter, “The Big Squeeze,” about how people experience the forces of the economy and capitalism day to day.

contributors.name: Alvaro Bedoya
contributors.title: Senior Advisor
contributors.details: Alvaro Bedoya is a Senior Advisor at the American Economic Liberties Project. He was appointed by President Joe Biden to serve as a Commissioner at the Federal Trade Commission in May 2022 and served in that role until his resignation in June 2025. At the FTC, Commissioner Bedoya focused on how antitrust law could do more to protect workers and labor unions and warned against rapidly advancing workplace surveillance technology. He took a special interest in the challenges facing small-town grocers and pharmacists and helped coordinate the Commission’s revival of the Robinson-Patman Act, a long-dormant antitrust law that was passed to give small sellers a level playing field against retail giants. He is a graduate of Harvard College and Yale Law School.

contributors.name: Lindsay Owens
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: Lindsay Owens, Ph.D., is the Executive Director of the economic think tank Groundwork Collaborative and author of the forthcoming book, GOUGED: The End of a Fair Price in America. Widely known for her ability to communicate pressing economic concepts and arguments, Lindsay has been credited with changing the way we understand inflation by leading the charge to expose – and articulate – the role of firm pricing power and corporate profiteering in price increases. Previously, Lindsay served as a senior economic policy adviser to Sen. Warren, and deputy chief of staff and legislative director to Reps. Ellison and Progressive Caucus Chair Jayapal. She holds a Ph.D. from Stanford University and a Bachelor’s degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

description: Corporations are weaponizing your personal data to inflate prices, suppress wages, and undermine transparency and basic fairness. This panel will expose how a convergence of corporate power and new technology has created a dizzying array of deceptive pricing practices. From surveillance pricing on airfares to algorithmic price fixing by landlords, companies are leveraging troves of consumer data to rip off customers. Our panelists will share how they have successfully defeated some of these nefarious practices and what policymakers, regulators, and consumers can do to fight back.

She directs and writes documentaries, commercials, branded content and all forms of human-centered storytelling that shift people's attitudes and behavior and shape culture. Cheryl also gives inspirational keynotes and workshops globally on how to use the craft and science of storytelling to move people deeply and coaches high level execs to help them shape their stories. Some of Cheryl's credits include feature documentary GENERATION STARTUP following 6 young people launching startups in Detroit, TRUTH TO TRANSFORMATION about the overhaul of the foster care system in NJ, web series, commercials and launch videos.

name: Flag Football’s Startup Moment: Building a Global Sport for LA28

contributors.name: Stephanie Kwok
contributors.title: VP, Head of Flag Football
contributors.details: As VP and Head of Flag Football at the NFL, Stephanie Kwok leads the League’s flag football strategy and programs in the U.S. and globally, driving participation, engagement, and fandom. As part of her role, Stephanie is focused on growing the sport for girls and women, creating high school and college opportunities, and partnering with IFAF and LA28 on flag football’s debut on the Olympic stage in Los Angeles in 2028. Stephanie has been part of the flag football ecosystem for the last 15+ years, playing in leagues in New York City and operating a tournament company. Previously, Stephanie held roles at FanDuel, Madison Square Garden, and Parthenon-EY. Stephanie earned an MBA from Harvard Business School and a BA in Political Science from Stanford University, where she was co-captain of the varsity squash team and a member of the national championship women’s club rugby team. She serves on the Board of Directors for Henry Street Settlement and co-founded/runs the Hell’s Kitchen Community Cupboard.

contributors.name: Diana Flores
contributors.title: World Champion, Quarterback & Captain
contributors.details: Diana Flores is the Captain and Quarterback of Mexico’s World Champion National Flag Football team. Flores also serves as a highly sought after game analyst and sports broadcaster for major networks like FOX Deportes and Univision, including coverage of Super Bowl LVIII. Working alongside the NFL and the International Federation of American Football (IFAF) as the sport’s Global Ambassador, Flores seeks to advance Flag’s reach internationally.A flag football superstar, Flores has competed in numerous national and international tournaments, representing Mexico on the world stage. She has won several awards and accolades throughout her career, including four National Titles since 2017, a Bronze World Cup Medal in 2016, a Silver Medal in 2021, Best Offensive Player at the World Flag Football Championship in Panama in 2018, and was named the Most Valuable Player (MVP) at the 2022 World Games where she led her team to a Gold Medal.Flores was also recently recognized by FORBES MAGAZINE in their prestigious “30 Under 30″ List for the Class of 2024. She also served as the Offensive Coordinator for the AFC at the 2023 NFL Pro Bowl Games – alongside head coach, Peyton Manning— and was the featured star in the NFL’s Super Bowl LVII advertisement, “Run With It,” which won an Emmy in 2023.

contributors.name: Cynthia Frelund
contributors.title: Reporter / Analyst
contributors.details: Cynthia Frelund is NFL Media's first analytics expert, contributing to a variety of NFL Network marquee shows and platforms. She appears on NFL GameDay Morning, NFL Fantasy Live, and NFL GameDay View. Frelund also provides on-site coverage for major events like the Super Bowl, NFL Scouting Combine, and NFL Draft.Before joining the NFL, Frelund worked at ESPN as a Predictive Analytics Analyst for two years. Prior to that, she served as a business development manager at Disney ABC Television Group and a finance analyst for the NFL.Born and raised in Okemos, Michigan, Frelund graduated from Boston College with a B.S. in Biology in 2005. She later earned an MBA in Finance, Entrepreneurship, and Innovation and pursued an M.S. in Predictive Analytics at Northwestern University.Outside of her professional career, Frelund is a dedicated marathon runner, having completed 25 marathons across 25 states. She is also actively involved with Bright Pink, a national nonprofit focused on preventing breast and ovarian cancer in young women.

contributors.name: Drew Brees
contributors.title: Nfl Legend
contributors.details: Drew Brees is the former 2009 Super Bowl MVP-winning quarterback for the New OrleansSaints. A native of Austin, TX, Brees attended Westlake High School and earned his Bachelor’sdegree in Industrial Management from Krannert School of Management at Purdue University,while lettering in football from 1997-2000. Drew went on to play five years with the San DiegoChargers and fifteen years with the New Orleans Saints. He has been elected to 13 Pro Bowlswhile being named 2004 Comeback Player of the Year, 2006 All-Pro Team, 2006 Walter PaytonNFL Man of the Year, 2008 and 2011 NFL Offensive Player of the Year, and Super Bowl XLIVChampion and MVP.As much pride as Brees takes in his on-field performance, he takes even more pride in hiscommunity service endeavors. Drew and his wife, Brittany, established the Brees DreamFoundation in 2003 and since then have contributed over $50,000,000 to help improve thequality of life for cancer patients and provide care, education and opportunities for children andfamilies in need. In addition to his personal foundation, Drew has co-founded SHIELD 1Foundation to address the greatest needs in our communities including but not limited tohousing, healthcare, education, business opportunity, economic development, urbanfarming, support of HBCUs, social justice and legislative reform.Brees is a proud partner of the GBX Group, Jimmy Johns, Walk-Ons Enterprises, Football NAmerica, Smalls Sliders, and Franworth. He participates as a Board Member for Surf Sports,Stretch Zone, Franworth and formerly with the NFLPA and President’s Council for Fitness,Sports and Nutrition.Brees has also proudly participated in five USO trips visiting Kuwait, Iraq, Afghanistan, Germany,Turkey, Djibouti, Dubai, Okinawa, and Guantanamo Bay. Drew currently lives with his wifeBrittany and children Baylen, Bowen, Callen and Rylen in San Diego, CA.

description:
Football is a cultural institution in America – it’s even taken over its own day of the week. But at the same time, its newest form, flag football, is still in its early stages. With the sport’s forthcoming debut at the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics, flag football is at an inflection point, scaling from community and high school leagues to the world’s biggest sporting stage.
 
In many ways, flag football is operating like a startup inside one of the world’s biggest legacy organizations. It has the agility, accessibility and grassroots appeal of a disruptive product, while also having the NFL’s platform and resources to help it scale.
 
This session will explore how the sport is growing internationally, why it resonates with the next generation of athletes, and what lessons innovators can take off the field by learning about what it takes to create the next Olympic sport.

This session will explore how the sport is growing internationally, why it resonates with the next generation of athletes, and what lessons innovators can take off the field by learning about what it takes to create the next Olympic sport.

Co-author of bestseller Made to Sell: Creating Websites that Convert, she supports entrepreneurs through organizations like 1871, Chicago Innovation, and as board member at DePaul University's Coleman Entrepreneurship Center.For 14+ years, Chykalophia has delivered high-quality web design, branding, and UX services, helping 250+ businesses achieve 7-figure success. Their WBENC certifications, award-winning work, and 5-star Clutch rating distinguish them in the industry.Trusted by Verizon Small Business Digital Ready, Gold House Ventures, and SBDC for mentoring programs, Ari has been featured in Forbes, Thrive Global, and Buffer. In recognition of their outstanding work, Chykalophia was recently named to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce's CO—100: America's Top 100 Small Businesses list, solidifying their position as a leader in the field.

contributors.name: Ji-Sook Yim
contributors.title: Product Design Lead
contributors.details:
I'm a Product Design Lead at Alight Solutions, where I drive the design strategy and vision for Alight's AI-powered experiences across employee benefits and employer analytics platforms. Through my role, I collaborate with multiple teams, including product managers, researchers, engineers, accessibility, content design, and design systems. I bring 15+ years of experience, including 8+ years in UX research and design, with diverse perspectives shaped by my previous roles as a content strategist at a branding agency and as a merchandiser for an e-commerce startup. Outside of work, I am a mentor on ADPList, providing mentorship to aspiring designers with resume and portfolio reviews, and to designers looking to grow their career into more senior or management roles. 

As a mentor, I can help with: - Questions around the changing landscape of the product design role in face of AI tools and the blurring division of roles between product managers, engineers, and designers - Using AI tools for team productivity and efficiency - Designing for experiences powered by AI - Forging cross-functional partnerships to drive strategy, and breaking out of the ""execution-only"" design role - Showing value as a designer as an essential member of the product trio

contributors.name: Laurel Prime
contributors.title: AI Lead, Sr. Partner Manager
contributors.details: Laurel Prime is an award-winning entrepreneur, investor, and technologist at Google. As a founder/operator, she built companies in media, edtech, and consumer genAI - backed by Peter Thiel and partnering with industry leaders like Character AI. Now, Laurel advises bleeding edge startups, serving on the board of the Entrepreneurship at Cornell and Harvard iLab ecosystems. At Google, Laurel is an Partner Manager in Ad Sales and a Product Manager on the Cloud AI team. She has led Google-wide hackathons, accelerating the internal adoption and launch of Gemini throughout Google and Alphabet. Beyond Google, Laurel serves as Google’s Chief Technical Representative in the AI Alliance, where she is setting industry standards for ethical AI development through benchmarks, tools, and methodologies that ensure responsible innovation.Prior to Google, Laurel studied CS and Applied Economics & Management at Cornell, and she is currently pursuing Executive Education in Artificial Intelligence at Stanford.

name: Mentor Session: Andee Connors (Pandora AMP / SiriusXM)

contributors.name: Andee Connors
contributors.title: Sr Manager - Catalog & Creator Services/Head of Metal, Punk, New Age & Experimental Programming
contributors.details: I am a drummer, musician, artist, DJ, music curator, former record store owner and former record label owner. I manage the Catalog & Creator Services team at Pandora / Sirius XM. We oversee Pandora’s AMP creator tools and help artists navigate the world of streaming services, promote their music and manage their careers. I also program Metal, Punk, New Age and Experimental music on Pandora. I ran a store called aQuarius recOrds in San Francisco from 1994 - 2016. There’s an Aquarius documentary out right now on Amazon Prime. I’ve been running tUMULt, a record label that has existed for 20+ years, with more than 50 releases. I’ve been playing drums since I was 9, touring and recording since I was 19. I played in all kinds of bands: math rock, noise-pop, punk rock, stoner metal, post rock and more. I also played drums in two performances with Japanese experimental outfit The Boredoms: in 2007 with 77 drummers, and then with 88 drummers in 2008. I still tour and record regularly with Common Eider, King Eider, a ritualistic doom/drone duo, and a doom synth duo called My Heart, An Inverted Flame. I live on the top of a mountain in the middle of the woods with one panther-sized cat, four special needs kittens, two goats and one bunny named Mayonnaise.

His focus is on engaging the publishing and songwriting communities, growing partnerships with music publishers and those who control compositional rights, and improving the YouTube product for music partners via new technology and product offerings.Eric also works on direct songwriter and producer initiatives at YouTube; leading dozens of workshops with hundreds of writers from around the globe, empowering attendees to get the most out of the platform.An attorney by trade, Eric joined YouTube via music-tech startup RightsFlow, which was acquired by Google/YouTube in 2011.  In his free time, he is a co-founder of nonprofit animal rescue organization Animal Lighthouse Rescue, where he sits on the board of directors.

name: Mentor Session: Randy Haaga (SoSouth Music Distribution)

contributors.name: Randy Joe Haaga
contributors.title: President
contributors.details: Randy Haaga started his professional career in the music business as a drummer in the mid-80s. He later became the manager of a DIY rock band, touring the U.S. several times in his early 20s. It was a dream job, but came with little pay, no benefits, and no notice before it ended. Randy worked much of the 90s at Southwest Wholesale, a historically important outlet for Texas Rap and other regional music, serving as the initial CD and cassette distributor for many classic releases. During the same decade, Mr. Haaga opened a CD shop and launched an online store focused on the Texas underground rap scene that originated at Southwest Wholesale. The online store was among the first to distribute DJ Screw mixtapes, Swishahouse, Slim Thug’s Boss Hogg Outlawz, and other Texas legends to the world.Then, as the digital era began and physical product sales declined, Mr. Haaga was in the right place at the right time. He launched SoSouth Music Distribution in 2005, when iTunes was only two years old—years before Spotify was launched. The service quickly gained traction, attracting hundreds of significant customers within the first few years. Randy worked with artists and catalogs such as DJ Screw, Big Moe, Lil’ Keke, Slim Thug, Z-Ro, and later breakout acts like Megan Thee Stallion and Finesse2Tymes, among others. Mr. Haaga continues to be the president of SoSouth Music Distribution, now distributing via Virgin Music Group, a part of Universal Music, along with the added service of SoSouth’s music publishing administration, which is partnered directly with Universal Music Publishing worldwide.

contributors.name: Sharon Arteaga
contributors.title: Senior Manager, Filmmaker Support
contributors.details: SHARON ARTEAGA is a film director from Corpus Christi, Texas, whose work playfully navigates themes of generational, linguistic, and cultural differences between people. Her award-winning short films include the 2021 HBO Latinx Short Film Competition Winner, When You Clean a Stranger's Home, now streaming on Max, and IN TOW, which received support from various funding entities and screened at the Oscar-qualifying Austin Film Festival and New Orleans Film Festival. Arteaga is a WarnerBros. Discovery 150 Artist, a Rainin Grant Fellow, and was a Gotham Market participant in 2022.She was a 2019 Tribeca Chanel Through Her Lens finalist and earned a Gold Signal Award while working as the Story Producer on the KUT/Identity Productions Tacos of Texas podcast. Arteaga is one of the founders of the Tejanas in Film and is the Sr. Manager of Filmmaker Support at the Austin Film Society. She is passionate about empowering others to make their own films.

description:
Typography is shifting fast—shaped by AI tools, new aesthetics, and a global wave of independent designers. In this session, two of the field’s sharpest trendspotters break down the seven emerging type trends poised to reshape branding, culture, and creative work in the year ahead. Expect a rapid-fire tour through what’s coming next, why it matters, and how you can use these signals to stay ahead of the curve.

Drawing on Monotype’s annual Type Trends report and the curatorial research behind the international exhibition Hundred Points, this conversation distills the most important patterns shaping visual communication today—and what they reveal about the future of design.

contributors.details: Helena’s diverse resume spans various fields within the music industry including artist management, music licensing, marketing, and key account management at NYC-based agencies. Her agency work included music supervision, music strategy, artist partnerships, audio branding and client support for brands and tech companies like Microsoft, Skype, Corona, Hertz, MOSCOT, and Rockbot.At Dolby, Helena led content licensing and strategy before being tapped to build music marketing as a new category. She was responsible for leading the brand's largest campaigns to date, featuring artists like Billie Eilish, Coldplay, Olivia Rodrigo, J Balvin, Justin Bieber, Lizzo, and Post Malone.At Fender, Helena led the Artist Marketing team and oversaw the LA and London-based artist relations teams to reinforce Fender’s leadership and dominance in the musical instrument space. contributors.name: Dr. Poonam Desai
contributors.title: Founder, Cmo Of Longevity Place, Founder Of Her Longevity, Longevity & Precision Med Expert, Lifestyle Medicine, Menopause Certified
contributors.details: Dr. Poonam Desai is a leader in the health industry working with high-profile clients worldwide, founder of a longevity center, a TEDx speaker, social media educator, consultant, and a mom. Her expertise spans precision medicine, functional medicine, anti-aging and longevity, menopause, perimenopause, fitness, nutrition, and health optimization. Dr. Poonam Desai, an osteopathic physician, is double-boarded in Lifestyle Medicine and Emergency Medicine and NAMS-certified in menopause care. Fellowship-trained in point-of-care ultrasound and precision medicine, she has also specialized in functional medicine and anti-aging medicine to help individuals optimize health and prevent disease. Dr. Desai has over 10 years of academic experience as faculty at Weill Cornell Medical School and NewYork-Presbyterian. Her keen interest in education led her to a prominent amount of following on her social media aimed to educate on health matters.

contributors.name: Rhonda Patrick
contributors.title: Ceo And Co-Founder At Foundmyfitness
contributors.details: Dr. Rhonda Patrick is a scientist and health educator recognized for her leadership in aging and disease prevention. As the founder of FoundMyFitness, she provides evidence-based insights to a global audience through her website and podcast. On YouTube, she engages millions in in-depth discussions on evidence-based strategies for improving healthspan.

contributors.name: Kayla Barnes-Lentz
contributors.title: Longevity Entrepreneur And The Most Publicly Measured Woman In The World
contributors.details: Kayla is one of the world’s top female longevity experts and has been studying female longevity for over a decade with speaking engagements all around the world.She has dedicated herself to the pursuit of preventative and regenerative methodologies aimed at optimizing female human health. Kayla has shared her labs and protocols and is the most publicly measured woman in the world. Her endeavors have garnered international recognition from notable publications and she has been named a top longevity leader globally. Kayla has been featured in: The Wall Street Journal, Harper's Bazaar, Fortune, Forbes, Business Insider, The New York Post, MSN, Yahoo, The Telegraph, The Independent, The Daily Mail, The Guardian and many more. Kayla was also a co-founder in one of the country’s most innovative longevity medical clinics.

name: Featured Session: Ibogaine in America:  The Parable of Our Time

contributors.name: Marcus Luttrell
contributors.title: Author
contributors.details: Marcus Luttrell is a retired U.S. Navy SEAL, Navy Cross and Purple Heart recipient, and #1 New York Times bestselling author of Lone Survivor.. Marcus is also the host of the Team Never Quit podcast and a nationally respected speaker on service, resilience, and leadership. He and his wife, Melanie, have been married for 15 years and are proud parents of three children.

contributors.name: Bryan Hubbard
contributors.title: Chief Executive Officer
contributors.details: Bryan Hubbard is the Chief Executive Officer of Americans for Ibogaine (AFI), a nonprofit advancing education and awareness about ibogaine as a potential breakthrough treatment for substance use disorders, brain injuries, and mental health conditions. A nationally recognized policy leader, Bryan previously served as Chairman and Executive Director of the Kentucky Opioid Abatement Advisory Commission, where he helped shape one of the nation’s most ambitious state-level responses to the opioid crisis. His career spans law, public policy, and healthcare reform, with leadership roles addressing disability policy, Medicaid, child support enforcement, and judicial responses to mental health and substance use challenges. Raised in Virginia’s coalfields, Bryan brings both personal heritage and professional expertise to his mission of building equitable solutions for communities devastated by addiction and trauma.

contributors.name: Dr Gul Dolen
contributors.title: Professor, Parsons Endowed Chair
contributors.details: Dr. Gül Dölen is a Professor and the Renee and Bob Parsons Endowed Chair in the Department of Neuroscience and the Department of Psychology, the Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute, and the Berkeley Center for the Science of Psychedelics at the University of California, Berkeley. Additionally, Dr. Dölen maintains an adjunct professorship in Neuroscience and Neurology at Johns Hopkins University and is the Director of the PHATHOM project (Psychedelic Healing: Adjunct Therapy Harnessing Opened Malleability). Dr. Dölen earned her M.D., Ph.D. at Brown University and MIT and completed postdoctoral training at Stanford University. Dr. Dölen is a pioneer and world leader of psychedelics research. Based on a series of breakthrough discoveries she has formulated the hypothesis psychedelics may be the long sought “master key” for unlocking critical periods across the brain. Importantly, understanding psychedelics through this framework dramatically expands the scope of disorders that might benefit from adjunct therapy with psychedelics. Dr. Dölen is the recipient of the Joukowsky Family Foundation Award, the Conquer Fragile X Rising Star Award, the Angus MacDonald Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching, the Society for Social Neuroscience Early Career Award, the Searle Scholars Award, and the Johns Hopkins University President’s Frontier Award.

contributors.name: Rick Perry
contributors.title: Chairman of the Board
contributors.details: Rick Perry served as the fourteenth United States Secretary of Energy from March 2017 to December 2019.  As Secretary, he was responsible for successfully executing President Donald J. Trump’s energy agenda and the expansive mission of the Department of Energy (DOE), including maintaining the safety and security of the nation’s nuclear arsenal, protecting the electric grid from cyber threats, ensuring access to reliable and affordable energy, overseeing scientific research and development, and promoting the development and export of American technology and energy all over the world. Under his leadership, the nation ushered in a historic energy era, becoming the number one producer of oil and gas in the world, a world leader in the production and generation of renewable energy, and the dominant global force in Supercomputing, Quantum Computing and Artificial Intelligence. Prior to joining the Trump Administration, Perry served as the 47th Governor of Texas from 2000-2015. As the longest serving governor of the Lone Star State, he championed conservative pro-growth principles that made Texas the world’s 12th largest economy and the economic envy of America. During his time in Austin, Governor Perry also implemented transformative reforms in the areas of security, criminal justice reform, energy, education, healthcare and the economy. As Chief Executive both as Governor of Texas and Secretary of Energy, Perry understood that the success of government is only as strong as its partnerships with the private sector. He advocated for smart regulatory reforms and strong public-private partnerships, empowering industry rather that creating more bureaucratic barriers. He started the Texas Enterprise Fund which lured hundreds of millions of dollars in private sector business and jobs to Texas. At DOE, he appointed the first ever Chief Commercialization Officer who was tasked with bridging the gap between the world-class R&D at the Department’s 17 National Laboratories and commercialization in the private sector. Rick Perry is a veteran of the United States Air Force, where he flew a C-130 tactical airlift aircraft in Europe and the Middle East. Throughout his career, he has been deeply involved in supporting both the active duty and veteran community, most recently as an advocate for using the power of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to deliver precision health care to warriors suffering from Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI), and other conditions.Perry earned distinction early in his life as an Eagle Scout. He was one of the first in his family to go to college, earning a degree in Animal Science from Texas A&M University, where he was a member of the Corps of Cadets and a Yell Leader. He is a lifetime member of both the NRA and American Legion Post #75.Perry married his childhood sweetheart, Anita, in 1982. They have two children, two beautiful granddaughters, and two handsome grandsons.

description: An ancient African medicine, Iboga, contains the most powerful psychedelic on the planet - ibogaine.  Known for decades in the underground of the West as a profound interrupter of drug addiction, U.S. military veterans have been fleeing to Mexico to access ibogaine treatment in a desperate struggle to save themselves from the physical, psychological, and spiritual ravages of war.  Recent medical discoveries related to ibogaine’s impact on the brain suggest that it may also be the most sophisticated molecule on the planet, holding revolutionary potential to transform the lives of millions across the world whose debilities are not responsive to synthetic pharmacology.  The pursuit of ibogaine’s medicalization within the United States is a daunting mission uniting diverse communities with common afflictions against institutional obstacles which expose and illuminate the dysfunctions of power over people as well as the monumental opportunity we now have for people to prevail over power.

She received her PhD from Northwestern, where she studied languageevolution and the development of social cognition. Prior to Amazon, she was at Adept andGoogle.

contributors.name: Michael Giannangeli
contributors.title: Head Of Product, Agentic AI - Nova
contributors.details: Michael leads Agentic AI for Amazon’s Nova foundation models, focused on building the capabilities for intelligent systems to reason, act, and scale in the real world. Before that, he helped grow Alexa from 1M to 100M+ customers, culminating in the launch of Alexa+. Along the way, he led the Echo and Echo Dot product lines to become the #1-selling product on Amazon.com, and founded Alexa’s computer vision initiative to make Alexa more personalized and adaptive. Before Amazon, Michael earned an MBA from MIT, worked as an economic consultant, interned on Wall Street and Capitol Hill, and played NCAA basketball.

contributors.name: Amanda Doerr
contributors.title: Vice President, Core Shopping
contributors.details: Amanda leads Amazon's Core Shopping organization, overseeing the end-to-end customer experience across homepage, navigation, product pages, reviews, and Alexa Shopping worldwide. She's at the forefront of AI-powered shopping innovation, leading teams that help customers discover, evaluate, and purchase products both within Amazon's store and across the web through agentic features like Buy for Me, which enables direct purchases from brand websites. Since joining Amazon in 2010, Amanda has driven product innovation across Kindle, Supply Chain Optimization Technology (SCOT), and Shopping. Prior to Amazon, she spent a decade at Microsoft leading global product launches for Windows and the Entertainment & Devices group.

description: Everyone's talking about AI agents, but what actually happens when companies deploy them to do real work? This live recording of the "Making a Mind" podcast explores the gap between how we think agentic AI should work and how it actually behaves in the wild. Cognitive scientist and podcast host Dr. Danielle Perszyk sits down with Michael Giannangeli, head of product, agentic AI for Amazon Nova, plus industry voices from Amanda Doerr, vice president of core shopping at Amazon and more who've recently launched agents into production. Together, they'll dissect real implementation stories—the successes, the surprises, and the moments where human expectations collided with AI reality. We'll explore the fundamental questions emerging as AI agents become collaborators: Where do humans want control versus autonomy? How do we build trust with systems whose reasoning we can't see? And how does cognitive science research translate into product decisions—from tool-calling architecture to the design choices that determine when agents act independently versus ask for help? This isn't a demo. It's an honest conversation about what we're learning as agentic AI moves from theory to practice—and what it reveals about both artificial and human intelligence.

Together, they'll dissect real implementation stories—the successes, the surprises, and the moments where human expectations collided with AI reality. We'll explore the fundamental questions emerging as AI agents become collaborators: Where do humans want control versus autonomy? How do we build trust with systems whose reasoning we can't see? And how does cognitive science research translate into product decisions—from tool-calling architecture to the design choices that determine when agents act independently versus ask for help? This isn't a demo. It's an honest conversation about what we're learning as agentic AI moves from theory to practice—and what it reveals about both artificial and human intelligence.
sort: MAKING A MIND LIVE FROM SXSW: WHEN AI AGENTS LEAVE THE LAB

contributors.details: Dr. Sue Sisley, MD is Montana/Arizona-based physician practicing Internal Medicine & Psychiatry. Sue serves as Principal Investigator of nonprofit Scottsdale Research Institute for myriad FDA-approved randomized controlled trials examining safety/efficacy of LSD, psilocybin mushrooms & intact cannabis flower. Sue holds 7 different DEA schedule 1 licenses as researcher & manufacturer. 5 years ago, SRI secured the only DEA schedule 1 manufacturer license in US for farming whole cannabis flower & natural psilocybin mushrooms instead of synthetic molecule. contributors.name: Lee Christian Parker
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details:
Lee Christian Parker is an Executive Director and Banker at J.P. Morgan Private Bank. Lee works closely with some of the most influential clients in the Washington, DC area, including diverse business founders, women wealth creators, and endowments and foundations. She serves as a powerful champion in connecting clients with the full force of J.P. Morgan so that they may grow and protect their assets, and establish important legacies for future generations.  

Before joining J.P. Morgan, Lee was a Senior Vice President and Philanthropic Client Manager at Bank of America Private Bank. Previously, she directed philanthropic advisory services for the Greater Washington Community Foundation. She holds a B.A. in Communications from the University of Maryland.

contributors.name: Jamila Taylor
contributors.title: President and CEO
contributors.details: Dr. Jamila K. Taylor, Ph.D., president and CEO of the Institute for Women’s Policy Research, is a national health equity leader and seasoned health policy researcher. Throughout her 20+ year career, Dr. Taylor has championed the health and rights of women, promoting policies that ensure access to vital health care, including building support for abortion access, ensuring safe and compassionate reproductive and maternal health care, and dismantling structural racism within the US health care system. She has testified before Congress and published and presented extensively on various public policy issues. Dr. Taylor has held leadership positions in national organizations, such as the Center for American Progress, the Century Foundation, the National WIC Association, and others.

contributors.name: Anna Gifty Opoku-Agyeman
contributors.title: Doctoral Student
contributors.details: Anna Gifty Opoku-Agyeman is a researcher, writer, science communicator and activist, whose work has been featured in Teen Vogue, The New York Times, Slate Magazine, NPR, Fortune, Marketplace, and The Guardian. She is the co-founder of The Sadie Collective, the only nonprofit organization addressing the lack of Black women in economics and related fields. In 2020, she became the youngest recipient for the CEDAW Women's Rights Award by the UN Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women.

contributors.name: Angelina Spicer
contributors.title: Comedian/Founder
contributors.details: Angelina Spicer is a stand-up comic, writer, producer, actress, mother, and accidental activist who blends humor and advocacy to spotlight maternal health. Spicer’s groundbreaking advocacy has earned recognition from former President Joe Biden and Senator Kamala Harris for normalizing conversations around postpartum depression. She works with lawmakers as a March of Dimes ambassador, and collaborates globally with hospitals and U.S. Embassies promoting the Sustainable Development Goals. Spicer is the founder of Spicey Moms, an organization committed to ensuring gender equity in health solutions by redefining maternal care.

description: Remember when every brand promised to do better? In 2020, diversity and inclusion roles were created overnight, corporate pledges made, and equity became a buzzword. Fast forward to now, when those diversity offices and leadership budgets are vanishing, and DEI programs face contact attacks. Where does that leave leaders—especially Black women—who were once vaunted as symbols of progress? Expect data, sharp insights, and real stories as we unpack what it takes to create systems where Black women’s leadership can thrive even when equity isn’t trending.

name: Say Vagina: Platform Censorship, Algorithms, and the Cost to Women's Health

contributors.name: Alexandra Fine
contributors.title: CEO and Co-Founder
contributors.details: Alexandra Fine is the co-founder and CEO of Dame Products, a pioneering sexual wellness company known for its innovative products and mission to close the pleasure gap. Recognized in Forbes’ 30 Under 30 in 2018, Alexandra leads Dame Products in designing user-centered tools that enhance intimacy. Since its inception in 2014, the company has expanded its offerings and impact, all while advocating for women's health and breaking barriers in advertising.

contributors.name: Laine Bruzek
contributors.title: Co-Founder and Chief Marketing Officer
contributors.details:
Laine Bruzek is co-founder & Chief Marketing Officer of Evvy, where her mission is to close the gender health gap, starting with demystifying and destigmatizing vaginal health. 

Evvy’s innovative vaginal healthcare platform, powered by their first-of-its-kind vaginal microbiome test, is the first to combine state-of-the-art testing, precision care, and 1:1 coaching to give women and people with vaginas the care they deserve. 

Laine is a creative brand builder and designer, previously at Google Creative Lab and Tribeca Enterprises, where she spearheaded initiatives across branding, marketing, emerging tech, data privacy, and product strategy. 

At Evvy, she also authored “100 Effed Facts About the Gender Health Gap”, a coffee table book about disparities in medical research. She has been recognized by Forbes 30 Under 30, Inc Female Founders 200, InStyle, Create & Cultivate, and more. Her work at Evvy has received top honors from Fast Company Most Innovative Companies, Innovation By Design, World Changing Ideas & Brands That Matter and The Webby Awards. 
 
Laine received her B.S. in Product Design Engineering and M.S. in Management Science & Engineering from Stanford University, where she was a Mayfield Fellow.

contributors.name: Monica Cepak
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Monica Cepak, MBA, is the first female CEO of Wisp, the largest pure play women's telehealth company in the U.S. focused on providing sexual and reproductive health solutions. Monica has been instrumental in expanding Wisp's services to address various aspects of women's health and has grown its user base to over 1.5 million patients. She has launched 30+ products during her year and a half as CEO—  including a fertility vertical, menopause care solutions, and at-home testing options. AdAge’s 40 Under 40  highlighted her as a leader in women’s health in 2024, showcasing her 20+ years of experience in brand and marketing leadership, and work across Fortune 500 companies.

description: Across the country, platforms like Meta and the NYC MTA are blocking ads and posts that mention vaginal health, fertility or menopause— censoring essential medical terms and allowing misinformation to spread. In this panel, brand leaders and marketers will explore how censorship is shaping the way women’s health is discussed— or not discussed— in public spaces, and how companies are navigating censorship challenges. It will examine why naming matters and how bold, stigma-breaking messaging can educate, empower, and shift the narrative.

It will examine why naming matters and how bold, stigma-breaking messaging can educate, empower, and shift the narrative.

contributors.name: Michele Y. Smith
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Michele Y. Smith is the CEO of the Museum of Pop Culture (MOPOP). Her people-centered leadership approach is the driving force behind her work at MOPOP which emphasizes a steadfast dedication to the democratization of philanthropy, the universal language of pop culture, diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility, and mentorship of emerging leaders. Prior to her role at MOPOP, Michele served as the Chief Business & Financial Officer at the award-winning cultural institution, the Woodland Park Zoo, where she played a pivotal role in navigating the organization through the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Seen in Observer, Hyperallergic, Forbes)

contributors.name: Christophe Laudamiel
contributors.title: Master Perfumer
contributors.details: Christophe Laudamiel is the Master Perfumer at Generation by Osmo. He is actively involved in fundamental research in scent digitalization as well as the selection of new captive molecules. Over the last 20+ years, he has worked at or with prominent industry companies including Procter & Gamble, International Flavors & Fragrances (IFF), Firmenich and Mane, and the largest air management company in the world for shows at the Guggenheim Museums; founded his own company, DreamAir studios; composed top scents such as Abercrombie & Fitch, Béyoncé, Clinique, Tom Ford, and more. His passion to teach and protect the art and ethics of Perfumery at the highest level, to defend every single ingredient of value, be it molecular or natural, has been widely recognized.

contributors.name: Alex Wiltschko
contributors.title: Founder and CEO
contributors.details: Alex Wiltschko is Founder and CEO of Osmo and Generation by Osmo, on a mission to give computers a sense of smell. He is a repeat entrepreneur and has spent much of his career exploring new frontiers and building businesses at the intersection of AI and biology. Previously, he was a research leader at Google DeepMind, has founded and exited two AI companies (Syllable, sold to Neumora; Whetlab, sold to Twitter), and was named to the Top 100 people in AI by Business Insider. Alex holds a Ph.D. in Olfactory Neuroscience from Harvard University. (Seen in Fortune, CNBC, Glossy, Axios)

contributors.name: Kaitlyn Barclay
contributors.title: CEO and Co-Founder
contributors.details: Kaitlyn is the CEO and co-founder of Scout Lab, an acclaimed creative communications agency that works with scaling disruptor brands, as well as global players like Adidas, Wix, Venmo and Casetify. She volunteers her time as the Data Director of Do The WeRQ, an organization that aims to increase queer creativity and representation in the marketing industry. Her writing has also been featured in Adweek, McSweeney’s, Glamour, Fast Company. Before Scout Lab, Kaitlyn led acquisition marketing at Levi Strauss after selling her startup to ClassPass in 2015.  She has her MBA from Columbia Business School.

name: Encrypted Resistance: Youth Revolt in Memes, Art & Metadata

contributors.name: Angelo Sathorn
contributors.title: Thai youth-led movement leader, member of United Front of Thammasat and Demonstration
contributors.details: Angelo Sathayu Sathorn is a Thai youth activist and law student at Thammasat University, recognized for his leadership with the United Front of Thammasat and Demonstration (UFTD). He joined the pro-democracy protests at age 17 during Thailand’s 2020 movement, as “the second wave” of the youth-led protest, advocating for constitutional reform, monarchy reform, and human rights. Angelo has spoken about the cultural shifts sparked by youth activism and the legal and political pressures faced by protestors. He envisions a democratic Thailand built on equality, truth, and reason, free from the cycles of conflict that shaped his generation.

contributors.name: Eva Galperin
contributors.title: Director of Cybersecurity
contributors.details: Eva Galperin is Director of Cybersecurity at the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), leading global efforts to protect vulnerable communities, from journalists and activists in repressive regimes to survivors of domestic abuse, from digital threats such as malware, spyware, and stalkerware. With a background in political science and international relations and early experience in Silicon Valley IT, Eva bridges technical expertise and human-rights advocacy. Since joining EFF in 2007, she has led critical initiatives like the EFF Threat Lab, the Tor Relay Challenge, and co-founded the Coalition Against Stalkerware, pushing the boundaries of how technology and policy can protect the world’s most vulnerable users.

contributors.name: Xiao Qiang
contributors.title: Research scientist at UC Berkeley School of Information; Founder, Editor-in-Chief of China Digital Times
contributors.details: Xiao Qiang is a research scientist at UC Berkeley’s School of Information and the director of its Counter-Power Lab, where faculty and students explore how technology, censorship, and digital rights intersect. He is also the founder and Editor-in-Chief of China Digital Times (CDT), a pioneering bilingual news site that serves as a global archive of encrypted resistance, tracking censorship patterns across China’s expanding digital empire. Trained in theoretical physics at the University of Science and Technology of China and the University of Notre Dame, Xiao shifted from science to human-rights technology after the 1989 Tiananmen Massacre. His work bridges data science and activism, revealing how creativity, coded speech, and diaspora networks defy algorithmic repression worldwide.

contributors.name: Joan Donovan
contributors.title: Assistant Professor of Journalism and Emerging Media Studies
contributors.details: Dr. Joan Donovan is a sociologist and Assistant Professor at Boston University, specializing in disinformation, media manipulation, and technology’s impact on democracy. She previously led research at Harvard Kennedy School, UCLA, and Data & Society. Donovan is the founder of the Critical Internet Studies Institute and co-author of Meme Wars. Her work combines academic rigor with public engagement, helping journalists, technologists, and civil society navigate today’s complex media landscape.

description: As authoritarian regimes from Beijing to Tehran expand digital control through AI-powered surveillance, censorship algorithms, and language policing, free expression faces coordinated attack. These systems now share tools of repression across borders. In response, youth resist in whispers—through irony, creativity, and digital dexterity, they craft encrypted defiance. This panel explores how coded memes, subversive slang, guerrilla art, edgy rap lyrics and diaspora networks fuel encrypted defiance, reshaping protest through cracks in the digital firewall—online and on the ground.
long_description: As authoritarian regimes from Beijing to Tehran expand digital control through AI-powered surveillance, censorship algorithms, and language policing, free expression faces coordinated attack. These systems now share tools of repression across borders. In response, youth resist in whispers—through irony, creativity, and digital dexterity, they craft encrypted defiance. This panel explores how coded memes, subversive slang, guerrilla art, edgy rap lyrics and diaspora networks fuel encrypted defiance, reshaping protest through cracks in the digital firewall—online and on the ground.
sort: ENCRYPTED RESISTANCE: YOUTH REVOLT IN MEMES, ART & METADATA
track_display_name: Culture

name: Streaming Fraud: Where We Are and How it's Changing

contributors.name: Tori Leche
contributors.title: Senior Manager, Fraud Prevention
contributors.details: Tori Leche is a versatile music industry professional with 8 years of experience in digital music distribution and a dual degree in Music Business/Management and Songwriting from Berklee College of Music. They also co-founded Pink Line Management, a boutique artist management company specializing in bespoke release plans and event planning. Tori currently works at UnitedMasters as the Senior Manager, Fraud Prevention. While they have successfully helped reduce artificial streaming at multiple distribution companies, Tori has also engaged with countless artists to educate them on how to avoid artificial streaming and protect their catalogs. Tori is passionate about helping independent artists succeed, which is why they approach fraud prevention with an education-forward mentality.

contributors.name: Kevin Rutherford
contributors.title: Senior Charts/Data Analyst, Streaming Services & Rock
contributors.details: Kevin Rutherford is a senior charts/data analyst in Billboard's charts department, with a focus on streaming data, social media/short-form video services and the rock and alternative genres.

contributors.name: Josiah Albertsen
contributors.title: Associate Director, Music Licensing
contributors.details:
I'm the Associate Director of Music Licensing at SiriusXM+Pandora. I work with our  label partners every day on any old content need that comes up. I'm the licensing team rep for the SXM+Pandora Product Org, and help lead our spin fraud and GenAI detection strategies. I’m the company's DDEX and MusicBiz Board Rep and Co-Chair the DDEX Spin fraud WG. I also speak at events like SXSW, MusicBiz, and MusicBizTrust & Safety. Former cofounder/CEO of Parallel (VR for music). I’ve been apart of many nonprofits and now help the Lake Merritt Institute improve Oakland’s iconic lake. (I also like rowing on the lake!)

My path began with indie labels, touring, managing bands, and managing/talent buying at a DIY venue with a cool disco ball—always surrounded by people who live for music.

contributors.name: Andreea Gleeson
contributors.title: Strategic Advisor; Former CEO, TuneCore
contributors.details: Andreea Gleeson is the former Chief Executive Officer of TuneCore, Strategic Advisory to Believe, and a leading innovator in the music industry. After years as an eCommerce pioneer, she joined TuneCore in 2015 as a member of the senior leadership team, rose to CEO in 2021, and has helped build TuneCore into one of the most dynamic and innovative companies in the music industry. Her support of independent artists has driven the implementation of leading-edge product & technology solutions and artist development programs, establishing TuneCore as the premier development platform for self-releasing artists. Since 2021, Andreea has been included in multiple Billboard Power Lists and, under her guidance as CEO, TuneCore was included in Fast Company’s list of the Most Innovative Companies in the music industry from 2023-2025.

description: Even after the first U.S. federal streaming fraud lawsuit in 2024, fraud and anomalous behavior remain major challenges. This panel explores recent developments, how AI is shaping both the problem and the solution, and who’s most impacted. We’ll share personal anecdotes, current case studies, and a ground-level view of how streaming fraud has evolved. We’ll also discuss what’s being done now (besides yelling into the void or shaking our fists at bots)

name: Building the Alien: Morphology, Mutation & Future Life

contributors.name: Shane Griffin
contributors.title: Artist & Director
contributors.details: Shane Griffin is an artist and director whose work fuses high-end design, live-action filmmaking, and emerging technologies. Seamlessly blending surrealism with futuristic themes, his distinctive visual language has attracted collaborators such as Apple, BMW, Givenchy, and Nike. Named a Louis Vuitton “200 Visionary,” ADC Young Gun, and TED Speaker, Shane’s ability to combine cinematic craft with cutting-edge design continues to push the boundaries of innovative storytelling.

contributors.name: Claire Isabel Webb
contributors.title: Director, Future Humans
contributors.details:
Dr. Claire Isabel Webb is a researcher, writer, and program director at the Berggruen Institute, where she leads Future Humans, a research initiative exploring how life, intelligence, and technology might evolve in the long term.

Claire earned her Ph.D. from MIT in the history and anthropology of science. Her forthcoming book, Reflexive Alienation, explores how scientists have imagined and anticipated alien life through speculative experimentation.

description: What if we didn’t just search for alien life—but built it? Drawing from Proxima Kósmos, a research project exploring how life and intelligence might emerge under radically different conditions, this session examines the intersection of scientific experimentation and design. Claire Webb and designer Shane Griffin present Xenoterra—a modeled world inspired by evolutionary robotics and AI—that reimagines how we define life itself.

description: Serious products don't have to be seriously boring. In fact, a little play might be the power-up your product needs. This talk explores how proven game mechanics like feedback loops, progression systems, and "juice" can supercharge your product's design, making it intuitive and addictive (in a good way!). Drawing from indie game dev, client work with major brands, and 40+ game jams, I'll show you how thinking like a game designer creates playful, emotionally resonant experiences. Learn to make your products more rewarding, alive, and user-loved. When in doubt, add more "juice"!

name: Does Better Health Start with Dignity?

contributors.name: Jewel Jones
contributors.title: Global Inclusion & Health Equity Practice Leader
contributors.details:
Jewel Jones serves as Executive Vice President of Global Inclusion & Health Equity at Real Chemistry, where she leads a team of experts who work with health care companies on actioning health equity as a business imperative. Jewel's team incorporates evidence-based considerations and community-first approaches to help unlock more options for more patients to experience better health – regardless of race, gender, zip code, or socioeconomic status. 
Jewel has designed and launched initiatives that have driven an increase in trustworthiness – for example resulting in high vaccine adoption in historically excluded communities. She has also created narrative-shifting and culturally-responsive engagements that have garnered media coverage in top-tier news outlets.
Jewel is deeply engaged in community and is an active member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. She is a graduate of Hampton University, where she serves on the advisory board for the School of Journalism and Communications.

contributors.name: Ivor Braden Horn
contributors.title: Investor, Physician, & Technology Executive
contributors.details: Dr. Ivor Braden Horn has over two decades of experience as an advisor, investor, physician, and technology executive with experience in entrepreneurial, venture, academic medicine, health systems, and research organizations. She is internationally recognized for her work at the intersection of technology, equity, and responsible health innovation. As the founding director and first Chief Health Equity Officer at Google, she led strategies to integrate health equity and responsible innovation into research and product development. Dr. Horn has held leadership roles at Accolade (acquired by Transcarent), Seattle Children’s Hospital, and the University of Washington School of Medicine. She currently serves on the boards of Boston Children’s Hospital, and Acclinate.

description: What does dignity feel like in health experiences and outcomes? Why does it matter now more than ever?  We’ll explore the role of dignity as a transformative force and unpack its emerging as a vital indicator of health quality, trust and connection. Dignity is reflected in how we’re treated, heard and how care is delivered. When it’s missing, the consequences are profound. As we evolve and reimagine the healthcare ecosystem so that it works better for everyone, health dignity offers a powerful lens that reveals opportunities to improve how help make health innovation real for more people.

name: Mallory's Ghost

contributors.name: Arabella Oz
contributors.details: Arabella wrote "Mallory’s Ghost" while working as a mental health counselor in Manhattan, after a circular road from film school to therapy and back again. Her work explores psychological patterns (the ones that don’t seem to quit) while honoring that life is also strange, funny, and beautiful. Her favorite pastime is laughing with her husband and collaborator, Nick Canellakis.

long_description: Mallory, plagued by fears of being unremarkable, joins her playwright boyfriend Sam on a retreat to coastal Maine. When she learns he once brought his glamorous ex, Louise, there, she’s struck with an obsessive curiosity about his past. As her jealousy takes hold, Mallory becomes convinced she’s being haunted by the ghost of Louise herself... Pulled into a journey that slips between past and present, rivalry and affection, melancholy and creativity, Mallory drifts further from her old life and toward something essential. "Mallory’s Ghost" is a psychological and playful exploration of envy, and the strange path it can lead back to the Self.

name: Mam

contributors.name: Nan Feix
contributors.details: Nan Feix is a filmmaker weaving stories of education, heritage, and family through subcultures like skateboarding, food, motorbikes, and dance—crafting films, docs, and art projects that blend social impact with bold, cinematic exploration.

long_description: After falling in love with Vietnamese cuisine during a life-changing trip abroad, Jerald—a self-taught chef from small-town Texas—arrives in New York City with one goal: to open his own restaurant. Juggling odd jobs and secretly perfecting recipes in a basement kitchen, he’s running out of time and money. When he meets Nhung, a sharp-witted Vietnamese waitress, their unlikely alliance sparks a bold culinary journey. From improvised street hustles to a hidden speakeasy, they fight to turn Jerald’s dream into reality. A story of passion, resilience, and unexpected friendship in the heart of the city.

long_description: In A Cowboy in London, filmmaker Jared Christopher captures a rare portrait of Charley Crockett on the verge of global stardom. Shot in the verite tradition, the film follows Crockett during a whirlwind week in London: 3 sold-out solo shows at historic Hoxton Hall, candid tv, radio & newspaper interviews, tourist wanderings, and intimate moments with fiancee Taylor Grace, whose camcorder diary intertwines with professional footage. Between forgotten lyrics and celebrity cameos, Crockett confronts the state of America, Ai in music, and the music industry itself, revealing a vulnerable, defiant artist unafraid to speak truth while chasing greatness.

name: Vibrating Music Hammocks
long_description:
The Music Hammock transforms its fabric into a speaker, resonating your body with the frequencies of the music so you feel as if you’re lying inside a sound system. In our fast-paced society, we often disconnect from our bodies. This installation offers a full-body listening experience, shifting your attention from mental chatter into physical awareness. Experience sound not only through your ears, but through your entire body.

name: Featured Session: The Innovation Engine You’ve Never Heard of: Your Neighbor

contributors.name: André Zdanow
contributors.title: President
contributors.details: André Zdanow is the President of FirstBuild and the Executive Director of the Small Appliances division of GE Appliances. Prior to GE Appliances, Zdanow served as the Vice President of eCommerce at Gemaire Distributors, a division of Watsco and one of the world’s largest independent distributors of heating, air conditioning, refrigeration equipment, parts and supplies. Before that, he served as the Director at Watsco Ventures, where he oversaw the evaluation of all hardware and Internet of Things investments and distribution opportunities. He has additionally held senior positions at Mophie, StadiumRed Group, and the invention company Quirky, where he was also an early investor in the companies. Zdanow began his career as an entrepreneur operating his own bagel shop, and today is a father of two, the co-executive sponsor of the LouNet Affinity Group, and serves on the Board of Directors for Ronald McDonald House Charities of Kentuckiana.
