description: Traditional corporate innovation keeps ideas locked away until launch, but GE Appliances innovation arm, FirstBuild, has flipped the script—inviting passionate enthusiasts to co-create products from day one. The result is a 93% failure rate that just so happens to drive million-dollar successes like the Opal Nugget Ice Maker, which raised $2.7 million in crowdfunding after the community helped shape its development. This session will explore how major corporations can harness the power of co-creation, where rough transparency builds more trust than polished presentations, and where your best product ideas might come from a Reddit user with a 3D printer. Learn how FirstBuild proves that building in public, failing fast, and letting communities vote with their wallets creates better products than closed-door development—and why the future of innovation looks less like a pipeline and more like a playground.
long_description: Traditional corporate innovation keeps ideas locked away until launch, but GE Appliances innovation arm, FirstBuild, has flipped the script—inviting passionate enthusiasts to co-create products from day one. The result is a 93% failure rate that just so happens to drive million-dollar successes like the Opal Nugget Ice Maker, which raised $2.7 million in crowdfunding after the community helped shape its development. This session will explore how major corporations can harness the power of co-creation, where rough transparency builds more trust than polished presentations, and where your best product ideas might come from a Reddit user with a 3D printer. Learn how FirstBuild proves that building in public, failing fast, and letting communities vote with their wallets creates better products than closed-door development—and why the future of innovation looks less like a pipeline and more like a playground.

contributors.name: Lauren Stafford-Webb
contributors.title: Chief Marketing Officer
contributors.details: Lauren has served as Chief Marketing Officer of SoFi Technologies since 2019—she oversees all aspects of Marketing including product marketing, performance marketing, brand strategy & creative, media buying, public relations, and web. She joined SoFi from Intuit, where she led global corporate marketing, spearheading the delivery of the company’s first corporate brand strategy and campaign. Prior to Intuit, Lauren held marketing leadership positions at The Procter & Gamble Company, where she achieved impressive results while leading all marketing efforts and overseeing the P&L for some of the world’s most beloved household brands at different stages of growth and innovation. Lauren holds a bachelor’s degree in Finance from The Ohio State University Fisher College of Business.

contributors.name: Allison Stransky
contributors.title: Chief Marketing Officer
contributors.details: Allison Stransky is CMO of Samsung Electronics America, where she leads U.S. marketing and communications with a focus on AI-powered brand building and cultural relevance. She champions Samsung’s “AI for All” vision—delivering personalized, predictive, and privacy-centric experiences across devices and generations. A dynamic voice in engaging Gen Z and Gen Alpha, Allison blends creativity, technology, and purpose to build brand love, drive innovation, and ensure inclusive access to the future of smart living. She also oversees breakthrough campaigns that shift from product-first messaging to storytelling that resonates emotionally—bringing AI-enabled experiences to life in ways that are human-centered and deeply relevant.

contributors.name: Eleanor Hawkins
contributors.title: Reporter
contributors.details: Eleanor Hawkins is a communications strategist and writer at Axios. She authors Axios Communicators —  a weekly newsletter that examines how leaders, businesses, brands and employers communicate — and runs Mixing Board powered by Axios, a membership organization with over 1,000 of the top communications, marketing and corporate affairs professionals.

contributors.name: Brian Irving
contributors.title: Chief Marketing Officer
contributors.details: Brian Irving has more than two decades of technology and leadership experience across technology companies and household consumer brands. He has served as the CMO of Lyft since March 2024, while also leading iconic global brands including Meta, Eventbrite, Apple, Google, and Airbnb. He also previously served as co-CMO and VP of global digital marketing for Levi Strauss & Co. As CMO at Lyft, Brian leads all marketing, creative, and communications for the brand. This includes developing the strategy for and executing on all product marketing; brand and integrated marketing; marketing sciences; the creative studio; brand social media; and corporate, policy, brand, and product communications. He holds a Bachelors of Arts in international relations from Michigan State University.

Her modeling career became notable after she was runner-up of Britain's Next Top Model, Cycle 5 and the first international winner of America's Next Top Model, Cycle 18.Sophie’s bubbly personality, positive attitude and love of life has landed her on multiple television networks such as CW , NBC , E4, ABC , Living TV, Music Choice and multiple publications such as Vogue, Marie Claire, Nylon, Cosmopolitan and Harpers Bazaar.Having coined the name of “Illuminator” for lighting up any room , its a safe bet you will have a good time with this bubbly brit!

contributors.name: Kayla Williams
contributors.title: Publicist
contributors.details: Kayla J. Williams, founder of entertainment marketing agency kj pr, has over fourteen years of marketing and publicity experience across music, film, television, events and more. Since its launch in 2022, kj pr has led campaigns for a diverse roster of clients including the Oscar Nominated Short Films, indie rock band Mt. Joy, Nuthouse Sports, the legendary Arlyn Studios, Bob’s Dance Shop, Cattle Country Music Festival, alt-country supergroup Chaparelle, and creative studio Raw Cereal. Other recent work for the company includes support on major tours and events such as Hans Zimmer Live, Beyond Van Gogh, and the BLAST.tv Austin Major. Before founding kj pr, Kayla spent a decade in agency life leading campaigns for major companies such as Meta, Amazon Prime Video, Bravo, Netflix, Peacock, and Smosh. She also has worked on milestone events in Austin including: the Formula 1 United States Grand Prix, Moontower Comedy Festival, SXSW Film, Texas Medal of Arts Awards, Willie’s 4th of July Picnic, X Games Austin and more.Based in Austin, Kayla earned her Bachelor of Science in Public Relations from the University of Texas at Austin. She is a proud member of The Recording Academy and Women in Music. She serves on the Board of Directors for the SIMS Foundation.

name: Mentor Session: Tim Palmer ('62 Studios)

contributors.name: Tim Palmer
contributors.title: Producer/Engineer
contributors.details: Tim Palmer is a renowned producer and mixer with an extensive career spanning multiple decades, working with iconic artists such as Robert Plant, David Bowie, Tears for Fears, Ozzy Osbourne, The Goo Goo Dolls, and U2. Most recently, his work on The Psychedelic Furs’ latest album contributed to a remarkable milestone—UK Top Ten albums across five consecutive decades.A key highlight of Tim’s career is mixing Ten by Pearl Jam, one of the 50 best-selling albums of all time, which was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2021. He also received a Grammy nomination in 2001 for his work on U2’s All That You Can’t Leave Behind, which won the Grammy for Best Rock Album. That same record featured the Grammy-winning tracks Stuck in a Moment and Elevation, both mixed by Tim.Now based in Austin, Texas, Tim continues to collaborate with artists including Tears for Fears, Jason Mraz, Blue October, The Polyphonic Spree, H.I.M., and The Psychedelic Furs. In 2014, he mixed Billy Childs’ Map to the Treasure, an album that received three Grammy nominations.In recent years, Tim has worked alongside Grammy-winning producer Larry Klein, mixing projects for Kandace Springs, Lang Lang, Lizz Wright, Luciana Souza, and two multi-artist jazz tributes to Charlie Parker and Jacques Brel. He also co-produced Ville Valo’s (VV) latest album, which debuted at #4 in Germany, and mixed The Tipping Point by Tears for Fears, which reached #8 on the Billboard 200.Beyond the studio, Tim has served two terms as a Recording Academy Trustee and sits on the advisory board of Sonic Guild (formerly Black Fret), an Austin-based nonprofit supporting local musicians. Over the past four years, Sonic Guild has provided more than $3.5 million in grants and performance payments to Austin’s vibrant music community.

contributors.name: Trey Hicks
contributors.title: Founder/President
contributors.details:
Trey Hicks is a seasoned publicist and creative strategist based in Austin, Texas, with over a decade of experience shaping the stories and experiences behind live events, concerts, and festivals nationwide. 

As Founder and President of the boutique agency Painting Pictures, he works hand in hand with artists, event producers, and small business owners to bring their visions to life - from grand openings to intimate pop-ups to massive multi-day music festivals - by building excitement, fostering community, and creating meaningful connections between audiences and the spaces they gather in. Whether supporting global brands, high-profile executives, or beloved neighborhood staples in his own backyard, Trey is known for delivering tailored, high-impact results that cut through the noise.

In addition to his work in music and live events, Trey also supports clients across restaurants, bars, retail, venues, nonprofits, and more, bringing a broad perspective on culture and community. He also proudly participates in industry mentor programs each year, with past support to SXSW, Soho House, and The Recording Academy, among others.

name: Mentor Session: Priscila Santana (SummerStage NYC/Charlie Parker Jazz Festival)

contributors.name: Priscila Santana
contributors.title: Programming Operations Manager
contributors.details: With over 15 years of leadership in the creative economy, Priscila Santana is an award-winning cultural leader. She curates one of the United States’ most important festivals, the iconic SummerStage in Central Park, presenting free performances that celebrate the diversity of New York City and make world-class culture accessible to all. Priscila’s influence reaches far beyond New York. She has spoken at major international conferences in Morocco, Cape Verde, Colombia, Canada, Brazil, Spain and in 2025 she was invited as a mentor for the European Festivals Association’s Festival Academy. In recognition of her impact, she received the Portuguese Brazilian Award for her leadership in New York’s cultural scene.She is also a scholar, currently pursuing her doctorate at Columbia University, one of the world’s most prestigious institutions, where her research focuses on leadership, cultural policy, and Black feminist studies in dialogue with music education. An activist, she also directs the Kilomba Collective, the first collective of Black Brazilian women in the U.S., advancing a vision of racial justice, equity, visibility, affection, and care. Born and raised in Bahia, Brazil, Priscila now lives in the Bronx, New York City, and is the proud mother of Sofia Eloah.

name: Narrative Filmmaker Mentor Session: Greg Kwedar (Ethos)

contributors.name: Greg Kwedar
contributors.title: Filmmaker

image.credit: TIFF Portrait Studio by Norman Wong

contributors.details:
Greg Kwedar is a two-time Academy Award-Nominated filmmaker. His film SING SING garnered three Oscar nominations, along with nods at the BAFTAs, Critics Choice, and Independent Spirit Awards. It won the NBR Award for Best Adapted Screenplay. Greg co-wrote and executive produced creative partner Clint Bentley's TRAIN DREAMS. The decorated film went on to win the NBR for Best Adapted Screenplay and received four Oscar nominations including Best Adapted Screenplay and Best Picture.  

In 2024, Bentley and Kwedar launched their production company ETHOS to develop their own original, individual and joint projects, and to champion artists under the innovative and equitable financing model that they pioneered on JOCKEY and further developed with SING SING.

name: Future Relic: Failures, Disasters, Detours, and How I Made a Career as an Artist

image.alt_text: Future Relic: Failures, Disasters, Detours, and How I Made a Career as an Artist

contributors.name: Daniel Arsham
contributors.title: Artist
contributors.details: Daniel Arsham is an artist whose work blends sculpture, architecture, performance, and design into a singular vision shaped by time, memory, and material experimentation. His now-iconic “eroded” aesthetic—artifacts rendered as if excavated from the future—has become a signature visual language that speaks to impermanence, nostalgia, and transformation. Born in Cleveland and raised in Miami, Arsham became the youngest artist ever to work with legendary choreographer Merce Cunningham. His work is in the collections of the world's most acclaimed museums and he has collaborated with major brands from Dior to Adidas. He is the author of Future Relic: Failures, Disasters, Detours, and How I Made a Career as an Artist.

description:
“Inspiration is for amateurs. I’m a professional artist: I wake up every day and go to work.”

This is the mindset that transformed Daniel Arsham from a student scraping by in his Brooklyn studio into one of the most sought-after artists of his generation. In Future Relic, he breaks through the mystique of the art world and shows what it really takes to make it in any creative endeavor.  

He'll discuss the art of the grind: how to run a creative business and why surrounding yourself with ambitious, successful people is non-negotiable.

name: Documentary Filmmaker Mentor Session: PJ Raval (Unraval Pictures)

contributors.name: PJ Raval
contributors.title: Director / Producer
contributors.details:
PJ Raval is a queer, first generation Filipinx American award winning filmmaker whose work examines social justice issues through the lived experiences and stories of queer and marginalized communities. Named one of Out Magazine's 'OUT 100′, and POV / American Documentary 2024 Creative Visionary, PJ's body of film work has been distributed widely internationally and has appeared on platforms including PBS, Netflix, Discovery and Showtime.

PJ is a co-founder of the NEA supported queer arts organization OUTsider and he serves on the steering committee of the Asian American Documentary Network (A-Doc) where he is the co-creator and co-lead of the network’s Impact Initiative. He is a Guggenheim Fellow, a Soros Justice Fellow, a USA Artist Fellow, and a Producers Guild of America member, and a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences where he also serves as the Chair of the Asian Affinity Group.

description: Back by popular demand, this SXSW meetup reunites the data-obsessed and innovation-hungry. In a digital landscape that shifts daily, "analytics" is no longer just about reporting on what happened yesterday—it’s about architecting what happens tomorrow. As the gap between raw data and creative innovation narrows, the role of the analyst is evolving from observer to navigator. Whether you’re a digital analyst, a data scientist or a CMO, join us to move beyond standard KPIs and discuss advanced analytics in product innovation. Come swap war stories, debate ethics, and explore how data democratization is changing the creative process.

contributors.name: Jennifer Prohov
contributors.title: Content Strategist
contributors.details: Jennifer Prohov is the content strategist for Noema Magazine, an award-winning longform journalism publication. Her role sits at the intersection of creative production, global operations and audience cultivation — distilling complex ideas into insights and experiences that keep readers coming back for more. With her expertise, Noema has exponentially expanded. She previously worked with WFAA in Dallas, where her work covering the COVID-19 pandemic was recognized by the Texas Medical Association for excellence in health reporting. Prior to WFAA, she worked at WBIR in Tennessee as a digital content producer, with a focus on generating Instagram and newsletter audience growth.

contributors.name: Caroline Hwang
contributors.title: Editor-In-Chief And Founder
contributors.details: Caroline Hwang is the founder and editor-in-chief of Synonym Magazine, a magazine about the immigrant diaspora and third culture from a food and art lens. She has been in the food media industry for over 10 years, primarily as a creative before venturing into publishing Synonym Magazine.

contributors.name: Kyle Tibbs Jones
contributors.title: Co-Founder And Editor
contributors.details: Kyle Tibbs Jones is Co-Founder and Editor at The Bitter Southerner, the James Beard Award–winning media brand telling stories with its print magazine, books, podcast, a record label and commerce. At The BS, Kyle oversees the vision, voice, editorial, and creative for the brand. She also hosts the podcast, “Batch” (when it’s not on hiatus) and is the author of Your Heart Is Your Home, The Bitter Southerner's first children's book. Always anchored in storytelling, her career has meandered through advertising, PR, creative direction, TV and film. Kyle held creative director roles for companies including WSB-TV and Turner Broadcasting and PR roles at Sea Island Resorts and AMPR in NYC. Alongside her co-founders in 2013, Kyle started The Bitter Southerner, now on a mission to make America, and the world, a better place.Originally from the small North Georgia town of Dalton, Kyle now lives in Athens, GA.

contributors.name: Vico Puentes

contributors.details: Vico Puentes is the founder of TOMO mags and a seasoned creative and marketing executive. name: Featured Session: A Conversation with Nothing's CEO and Co-Founder Carl Pei

contributors.name: Carl Pei
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Carl Pei is a founder, product thinker, and challenger of the status quo. In 2020, he launched Nothing – a London-based consumer tech company on a mission to make tech fun again. Backed by GV (Google Ventures), EQT Ventures, and C Ventures, Nothing is one of the only independent tech companies designing and shipping hardware at scale. In just four years, it shipped millions of devices, surpassed $1 billion in lifetime revenue, and built a global community of more than 3 million people. Carl has been featured in Forbes 30 Under 30, Fortune 40 Under 40, and Marketing Week’s Vision 100. But he’s most at home obsessing over the details, building products that break convention and give people something to get excited about again.

description: Join Carl Pei for a wide-ranging conversation about where the tech industry is heading in 2026 - and why Nothing is on a mission to make tech for the next generation. In this session, Carl will reflect on how the consumer tech industry became closed and predictable, and why the next era will require a different mindset. He will share his perspective on some of the biggest shifts facing the industry, including the rise of AI-native hardware, and how AI is becoming a core part of the product experience. The conversation will also touch on Nothing’s own next chapter - from its continued push into audio to the brand’s growing physical footprint with new store openings planned across New York City, Tokyo, London, and India this year. Join Carl for a conversation about rebuilding belief in consumer technology, not by constant product launches, but thoughtful design, cultural relevance and products that people genuinely want to live with.

contributors.name: Frank Freeman
contributors.title: Vp Ai & Digital Disruption
contributors.details: Frank Freeman is Vice President of AI & Digital Disruption at Dermalogica and Unilever Prestige. Since 2017, he has spearheaded digital products such as Face Mapping AI Skin Analysis, The Book GPT for Dermalogica Professionals, and Clean Touch Certification for Skin Therapists, blending technology with education to deliver personalized skincare experiences. Frank now drives cross-brand AI strategy across the Unilever Prestige portfolio, helping shape how emerging technologies transform the future of beauty.

contributors.name: Jeremiah Andrick
contributors.title: Vice President Marketing, Software & Dtc
contributors.details: Jeremiah Andrick is a marketing executive who builds brands by aligning strategy, technology, and creative execution.As Vice President of Marketing, Software & DTC at SteelSeries, Jeremiah leads multinational teams focused on revenue growth, customer engagement, and building a brand presence that holds up across markets. His work spans commercialization strategy, digital transformation, and content platform development, connecting the technical and creative sides of marketing to drive measurable results.A technologist at heart, Jeremiah approaches growth marketing and customer experience design through the lens of data and emerging technology. He's built his career understanding how brands maintain relevance in digital environments, and he's committed to sharing that knowledge with the broader industry.He speaks at conferences, leads training sessions, and writes about digital marketing, with a focus on practical application over theory. Whether he's analyzing performance data, developing go-to-market strategies, or building out his team's capabilities, Jeremiah brings the same approach: make it strategic, make it scalable, and keep it grounded in what actually moves the business forward.

contributors.name: Marina Chilingaryan
contributors.title: Director, Content, Social & Community
contributors.details: Marina is a Director of Content, Social & Community with deep experience leading organic social, creator, brand and community strategies for high-growth startups and enterprise brands. She’s worked with companies like Oura Ring, MongoDB, Amazon (AWS), Match Group, Crunchyroll to build brands people want to follow — and communities they want to be part of.At NoGood, Marina built and leads the agency’s Creator and Organic Social studio, bringing together strategists, designers, copywriters, community managers and content creators to help brands show up meaningfully across the social ecosystem. Her team focuses on building social capital, turning engagement into brand momentum and making culture work for business.With roots in editorial and storytelling, Marina brings a sharp narrative lens to every brand she touches. She’s known for translating complex ideas into compelling, culturally fluent strategies that resonate across both technical and non-technical audiences.

contributors.name: Mostafa ElBermawy
contributors.title: Founder & Ceo
contributors.details: Mostafa ElBermawy is a serial entrepreneur and growth engineer with 15 years of experience driving growth for startups and Fortune 500 brands, including Microsoft, ByteDance, P&G, and Amex. He is the founder of Goodie AI, the end-to-end AEO platform that helps brands monitor and optimize their visibility across all major AI search surfaces, including ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Gemini. The platform combines multi-model intelligence with a closed-loop system built for the AI search and agentic web that now controls brand discovery.He is also the founder of NoGood, a premier growth agency in New York City. At NoGood, Mostafa has assembled a team of creative, performance, and engineering experts that helped many category-leading startups and scale-ups achieve rapid, measurable growth. Mostafa is a regular contributor to Wired, SkyNews, The BBC, and TechCrunch. In addition, he teaches courses on AI search and building AI-native teams through Reforge and Maven.

description:
Your marketing dashboard is likely missing half the story. Impressions, clicks, and keyword rankings were built for a world where Google sent traffic to websites. When 60% of searches end in AI-generated answers without clicks, those metrics don't fully connect to revenue. AI traffic from platforms like ChatGPT and Perplexity is already converting at 4-5x the rate of traditional search for some brands — but most marketing teams can't see it, let alone measure it.

This session introduces the measurement framework for AI-first marketing: answer share (how often you appear in AI responses), citation rate (how often you're referenced as a source), and AI-driven conversions (revenue from users who never clicked a traditional link). We'll discuss how to design attribution experiments that prove impact, connect your brand’s AI visibility to actual business outcomes, and build an executive dashboard that ties AI performance to revenue.
long_description:
Your marketing dashboard is likely missing half the story. Impressions, clicks, and keyword rankings were built for a world where Google sent traffic to websites. When 60% of searches end in AI-generated answers without clicks, those metrics don't fully connect to revenue. AI traffic from platforms like ChatGPT and Perplexity is already converting at 4-5x the rate of traditional search for some brands — but most marketing teams can't see it, let alone measure it.

This session introduces the measurement framework for AI-first marketing: answer share (how often you appear in AI responses), citation rate (how often you're referenced as a source), and AI-driven conversions (revenue from users who never clicked a traditional link). We'll discuss how to design attribution experiments that prove impact, connect your brand’s AI visibility to actual business outcomes, and build an executive dashboard that ties AI performance to revenue.

name: Resistance, Resilience, and Reality: The Fight for Trans Equality

contributors.name: Morgan J. Walker
contributors.title: Counsel
contributors.details: Morgan Jada Walker (she/her) is Counsel at Lambda Legal, the oldest and largest national legal organization committed to achieving full recognition of the civil rights of lesbians, gay men, bisexuals, transgender people and people with HIV.Morgan is a seasoned trial lawyer, appellate attorney, and public advocate, with more than two decades of experience in federal, state, and territorial courts, and the court of public opinion. Morgan has completed more than 50 jury and bench trials, six appellate court oral arguments before the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals and Alaska Court of Appeals, and resolved dozens of cases by negotiation.Morgan’s first case at Lambda was in 2025, when she joined a trial team that successfully fought for the Constitutional rights of an incarcerated transgender woman in Alaska who needed gender-affirming surgery.Before joining Lambda, Morgan served longer than eight years as an Assistant United States Attorney in the District of Alaska, where she investigated and prosecuted a wide variety of cases, including civil rights, environmental, national security, white-collar and transnational crimes, and child exploitation. Morgan’s special projects include serving as coordinator of the Anti-Terrorism Advisory Committee, Civil Rights Coordinator, and mentor for other attorneys.In 2022, Morgan was detailed to the American Embassy in Sri Lanka and U.S. Mission to Maldives, where she designed and delivered capacity-building programs for prosecutors and judges regarding counterterrorism, international financial crimes, digital evidence, and trauma-informed victim engagement. In her capacity as Justice Department leader at the mission, she served on the Embassy’s emergency-action committee during a political and economic crisis. In 2024, Morgan became one of the few (if only) transgender lawyers to prosecute a jury trial before transition and, later, after socially transitioning, defend the same conviction on appeal.Earlier, Morgan served as a state prosecutor for eight years, when she handled cases in urban and rural communities. Morgan focused on special-victims cases, involving minors and adults, and empowered dozens of survivors to testify. Morgan served as the deputy director of the Alaska Medicaid Fraud Control Unit, during which time she secured one of the largest contested restitution judgments in state history.Morgan’s prior legal work took her to American Samoa, where she served as both prosecutor and public defender, and to private practice in Seattle. Morgan earned her Juris Doctor in 2004 from the University of Minnesota Law School, where she was on the Dean’s List and participated in immigration and prosecution clinics. Morgan studied philosophy in politics at Earlham College.

contributors.company: a public school district in Texas
contributors.name: Indigo Giles
contributors.title: Special Education Paraprofessional
contributors.details: Indigo is an educator and activist who has been advocating for trans Texans for more than 5 years. They graduated from the University of Texas at Austin in May of 2024 with a bachelors degree in psychology. In their time at UT, they founded a student organization dedicated to providing volunteering opportunities to LGBTQ+ students, and served on the leadership board for three years as president, vice president, and communications officer. Since 2021, Indigo has testified before the Texas legislature against dozens of bills targeting transgender youth and has spoken out in support of trans kids in DFPS meetings, panel discussions, media interviews, and rallies. Currently, Indigo works as an educator in the Special Education department at a Texas public elementary school as well as the executive assistant to the director of Parents of Trans Youth, a social impact business providing learning and support to caregivers of gender-diverse kids. They also serve as the Chair for Alumni Service on their high school's alumni board. In their free time, Indigo can be found playing Dungeons and Dragons, crocheting huge blankets, and cuddling with their cats Tofu and Sesame.

contributors.name: Mo Jenkins
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details:
Mo Jenkins is a Black trans woman, a proud Texan, and a political strategist who has spent her life turning struggle into purpose. From navigating the foster care system and housing instability to rising through the ranks of Texas politics, her journey is defined by resilience, clarity, and an unwavering commitment to community.

Mo currently serves as Deputy Chief of Staff to State Representative Jessica González and as Executive Director of the Texas House LGBTQ Caucus, working at the intersection of policy and lived experience. Inside the Texas Capitol, her work is focused, strategic, and unapologetically people centered, grounded in the belief that the best policy is shaped by those closest to the pain.

Her political journey began as a trailblazer when she became the first openly trans person elected to student government at Texas A&M University–Corpus Christi, later serving as Student Body President. That same vision now guides her legislative work, where she has helped advance critical policies including the sickle cell disease registry and the burn pits registry fund, and played an instrumental role in the 2023 defeat of school vouchers through her work with Representative Abel Herrero on the landmark Herrero Amendment.

What drives Mo’s work is both memory and vision. Hearing elders say they “already took on this fight” as the same battles resurface fuels her determination to keep pushing for equality and justice, so the next generation will not have to fight these same wars again.

contributors.name: Sofia Sepulveda
contributors.title: Field Director
contributors.details: Sofia (she/her) is the Field Director at Equality Texas. She has over a decade of experience organizing for healthcare and environmental justice in San Antonio. She is the co-founder of Trans Power San Antonio and organizer of the inaugural Women’s March in San Antonio, as well as co organizer of the march of us, the March for Trans visibility. She sits on the board of Healthcare-Now, the Transgender Education Network of Texas, and the Community Advisory Board for CentroMed in San Antonio. In her free time you might find her doing yoga, hiking, cooking or spending time with her dog Maggie and her cat Hunty.

description: In the wake of a steep rise in anti-trans legislation and hostile rhetoric, how can we protect our communities and fight for a better future? Join leading trans advocates as they report from the frontlines—a teacher navigating classroom censorship, a lawyer challenging discriminatory laws, and an organizer educating the public while building community. Moderated by a long-time legislative staffer, this panel will explore what it takes to fight from the inside and survey the political realities in Texas. How is anti-trans legislation reshaping the lives of trans folks and the broader community? What does the path to equality look like, and what can we do to move in that direction? Get the facts and leave with actionable steps.

contributors.details: Celebrating his 35th year in the music industry in 2026, Michael Starr, runs the promotion department at indie-powerhouse, Glassnote Records, where he has spent the past 15 years launching/developing/supporting the careers of such artists as Mumford & Sons, Phoenix, CHVRCHES, Childish Gambino, Two Door Cinema Club, Jade Bird, AURORA, bby, Tors, Silvana Estrada and more.  Starr's career background also includes stints in retail management, marketing, and artist development.  Michael has spent his entire music career residing in Texas, and he's a proud Austinite who embodies the spirit of SxSW.  He's always happy to lend an ear, offer some input when asked for it, and encourages people to chase their dreams.Starr loves working closely with artists & managers to help guide them through today's ever-changing industry landscape to put them on the path to success, not just at radio, but at relationship-building, content creation, live show development, mental & physical health & overall well-being.Prior to his time at Glassnote, Michael had his fingerprints on the development & success of such artists as Evanescence, Seether, Creed, Drowning Pool from the 2000s, as well as Lit, Eve 6, Vertical Horizon, and more from the 1990s.

contributors.name: Juliane Dressner
contributors.title: Director/Producer/Cinematographer/Editor
contributors.details: Juliane Dressner is a director, producer and cinematographer whose  observational documentaries explore civil rights and other pressing societal issues. Her feature-length debut, PERSONAL STATEMENT, premiered as the opening night film at AFI DOCS, was broadcast on PBS and was nominated for an Emmy Award. Juliane’s other films include THE SCARS OF STOP-AND-FRISK, a documentary short that was part of an Emmy-winning season of the Op-Docs series from The New York Times. She won the National Magazine Award for Video for her short film, AN EDUCATION, which was published by The New York Times Magazine. She has also had films published by The Guardian, The Atlantic, New York magazine and Buzzfeed. She is the Director, Producer and Director of Photography of My NDA (2026), as well as of EDUCATING ELIZABETH (2027), which is currently in post-production and is supported by Latino Public Broadcasting.

She is currently in the hit Apple TV show Pluribus. Her work can be seen on Apple TV, HBO, Netflix, Disney+, FX, ABC, CBS, NBC and many other platforms.

description: The weaponization of NDAs is a core structural feature of the economy that shapes corporate culture. Using cases from My NDA (World Premiering at SXSW 2026), panelists will expose how NDAs are used to protect brands; enable discrimination, harassment, and corruption to go unchecked; and destroy the careers of whistleblowers who risk everything to speak out. Panelists (including two anonymous participants of the film) will also discuss what an ethical NDA looks like and the simple legislative fixes that can solve this problem.

Panelists (including two anonymous participants of the film) will also discuss what an ethical NDA looks like and the simple legislative fixes that can solve this problem.

name: Designing AI for Human Thriving

contributors.name: Anastasia Uglova
contributors.title: Co-Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Anastasia Uglova is the Founder and CEO of Better Half, a social AI company designing technology that models healthy relationship dynamics and strengthens real-world human connection. She coined the terms “agentic tech” and “tech for human agency” through her graduate research at the University of Texas at Austin, where she studied digital privacy, concealed influence, and cognitive consent — a framework that now informs the investment thesis of AI venture firm ex/ante, where she advises. Previously, she was a Specialist Leader in AI Security at Deloitte Government & Public Services. Her career spans government service, international education infrastructure in Rwanda, media operations at NPR and NBCUniversal, and academic research in privacy and influence.

description: AI safety won’t be solved with better guardrails. The real question is what we train AI to optimize for. Anastasia Uglova, founder of Better Half and the technologist behind “agentic tech,” argues that today’s systems reward engagement and dependency – especially in the relational domain. What if we designed AI for agency and human thriving instead? This talk explores why relationships are AI’s highest-risk and highest-potential frontier and how a new design philosophy could unlock entirely new forms of social technology.

description: What if your breathing patterns could warn you that you are getting sick days before you have noticeable respiratory illness symptoms? The answer lies in sleep audio analysis powered by AI. This session explores how new advances can help us detect patterns far before our bodies notice. Sound is passive, honest, and scalable, and with AI trained on 3B nights of data, it can turn every bedroom into a node in an early-warning health network. AI has the power to turn sleep audio into a new public health infrastructure: one that listens, learns, and helps us act before symptoms even appear.

contributors.details:
An industry innovator and award-winning creative, Suzana leads global teams advancing brand storytelling by connecting creativity to technology.
For the past 10 years, she's worked at Google NY across creative technology, media, and effectiveness roles. She led campaigns and innovation projects for Pixel, Chrome, YouTube, and Android, and currently focuses on incubating AI tools to drive marketing's AI transformation.
Before Google, Suzana held executive creative roles at JWT, StrawberryFrog, VML, and Anomaly, working with brands like Converse, Coca-Cola, and Fiat. She co-founded Hello Interactive and helped turn the Africa agency into Cannes' second "Agency of the Year" winner.
She has won multiple international awards and juried at Cannes Lions, the ANDY Awards, and the One Show.

contributors.name: Paul Aaron
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Paul Aaron is the co-founder of Addition, a leading applied AI company that partners with iconic brands to help them develop new capabilities by harnessing frontier AI technology. Addition works with clients like Google, The New York Times, NBCU, Prudential, and Realtor.com, and serves as a leading AI systems design studio for Google's ongoing AI marketing initiatives. Addition's work has been recognized in Ad Age and The Wall Street Journal, and honored at industry award shows like the Cannes Lions. In 2025 Addition joined the R/GA family as their first acquisition after R/GA exited from IPG to become independent. Paul regularly speaks at events such as Cannes, AICP, and the One Show, educating the industry on solving creative challenges with AI.

description: As technology has evolved—from mass media to digital to social—brands have developed new abilities to interact with humans. The real transformation that brands undergo with AI won't be just about efficiency, but rather about showing up in the world in new ways that are adaptive, contextually aware, and authentic. Through recent case studies from Google, we'll explore how brands are embedding human creativity into AI systems to enable entirely new forms of human-brand interaction—and why this shift demands a fundamentally different approach to creativity.

A process that once prioritized creators with the largest audiences & revenue streams has since evolved to working with a range of  creators, targeting those with the most engaged audiences. As the industries continue to grow & scale each year, recruiting, managing, measuring & tracking hundreds of creators can feel impossible, but it doesn’t have to. This panel explores how brands & developers are building smart systems that fuel high-performing evergreen creator programs.

He has led campaigns that boosted engagement and game sales across PlayStation, Xbox, Switch, Steam, and Epic, while building partnerships with Sony, Microsoft, Amazon, and Valve. He also serves as company spokesperson and oversees crisis response, public policy, and CSR initiatives.

name: Safety and Security in the Age of AI Autonomy

contributors.name: Numa Dhamani
contributors.title: Head of Machine Learning
contributors.details: Numa Dhamani is the co-author of Introduction to Generative AI, Head of Machine Learning at iVerify, and a lecturer at The University of Texas at Austin. She is a natural language processing expert with domain expertise in trust, safety, and security. She has built AI systems for social media platforms, Fortune 500 companies, and mission-driven startups, and she advises on AI safety, security, and governance. Numa has served as Principal Investigator on U.S. Department of Defense research programs, been a fellow at Yale Law School’s Information Society Project, and contributed to the first international study on hate speech with the University of Houston. She is passionate about building responsible AI and working toward a safer, more transparent digital ecosystem.

contributors.name: Maggie Engler
contributors.title: Member of Technical Staff
contributors.details: Maggie Engler is a Member of Technical Staff at Microsoft AI, where she leads technical safety for consumer Copilot. Maggie has spent her entire career in cybersecurity and trust and safety, and has built automated systems from fraud detection to content moderation. She is the co-author of Introduction to Generative AI and the author of the Global Internet Forum to Counter Terrorism (GIFCT) Red Team Working Group's report on generative artificial intelligence. Maggie has spoken at conferences including TrustCon and MozFest and has been a fellow at the Berkman Klein Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University and the Information Society Project at Yale Law School. She holds bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical engineering from Stanford University.

description: We’re entering an era where AI doesn’t just answer questions—it takes action. From calendar scheduling to full-stack coding, agentic systems are gaining autonomy, unlocking powerful capabilities and introducing novel risks. How do we secure systems that can act on our behalf? Who’s accountable when they fail? In this presentation, Dhamani and Engler, co-authors of the bestselling book Introduction to Generative AI, explore the future of safety, security, and human oversight in a world where AI systems don’t just assist us—they act for us.

contributors.name: Martin Rabaglia
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Martín  Rabaglia  is a transdisciplinary creative technologist and strategist, crafting award-winning cultural-tech experiences for over 15 years in Buenos Aires. As CEO & Co‑founder of Genosha since 2016, he has led projects for global brands like Intel, Nissan, Disney, Pepsi, and Tulipán—merging narrative design with AI, VR/AR, and immersive storytelling. His leadership helped Genosha win Argentina’s first-ever Gold Lion for Innovation at Cannes Lions 2025, reinforcing his reputation as a leading force in Latin American creative tech.

contributors.name: Franco Luca
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details:
20 years of experience in the Advertising Industry. Specialized in the Digital Communication Business. 

Now leading RAPP Argentina, the Omnicom Group agency with a team deliberately diversified with creative, data, strategy, and tech experts working together across capabilities to understand clients' needs, delivering creative solutions for their business problems. 
He's also leading Team × LATAM, the Omnicom Group agency for Mercedes-Benz.

Franco is currently a Board Member of Interact Argentina, the Association that brings together agencies, consultants, and production houses of the digital ecosystem.

He led and founded Digitas Argentina, the digital agency of Publicis Groupe in 2018. He also had the role of Chief Content Officer for Publicis Groupe Argentina, supporting all the agency brands in the country. For 2 years he led LiquidThread, the creative SBU of Publicis Media.

For 5 years he was the Digital Director in Human agency. He promoted local, regional, and global projects of social media, digital platforms, apps, and sites for brands such as The Coca-Cola Company, Moët Hennessy, Mondelēz, AB InBev, AXION energy, Puma, Nivea, Honda, Molinos Río de la Plata, Procter & Gamble, Motorola, and Danone.

Franco also has a highly active role as a Jury Member in Creative Festivals, with a notable highlight at Cannes Lions 2023, where he served as an awarding jury member in the Creative Data category. He has also been a jury member at international, regional, and local festivals such as Effie, El Ojo de Iberoamérica, ECHO LATAM, The Caples Awards, +Digital, Obrar, and Lápiz de Oro.

Along with his career, he worked on projects awarded at several festivals: Cannes Lions, Effie, Diente, Lápiz de Oro, Ojo de Iberoamérica, El Sol, +Digital, ECHO, and Wave.

Previously in different positions, he went through Vulgaria agency, where he worked for L'Oreal, Renault, Havanna, ICBC, and started his career at Wunderman in 2006.

description: As AI reshapes how we think, feel, and decide, this workshop explores how marketers, researchers, and creators can design more human-centered AI systems. Blending neuroscience, behavioral science, and real-world case studies, we’ll unpack the psychology behind trust, emotion, and collaboration in AI. Participants will leave with a framework for building AI that enhances—not replaces—human insight, helping teams navigate this new era with curiosity, empathy, and practical wisdom.

name: Anima

contributors.name: Brian Tetsuro Ivie
contributors.details: Brian Tetsuro Ivie is a Japanese-American filmmaker, film producer, and the co-founder of Kebrado, a celluloid-only media company based in New York City. His most recent producing work includes the Oscilloscope-released, "Wildcat," starring Maya Hawke, Laura Linney, and Cooper Hoffman, which debuted at both the Telluride and Toronto Film Festivals before premiering on the Criterion Channel, “Even in the Wind,” starring Sonoya Mizuno, which premiered at Internationale Kurzfilmtage Winterthur, and the upcoming 16mm workplace comedy, "Concessions," starring Michael Madsen, Steven Ogg, and Josh Hamilton. Brian is currently writing an original science-fiction series with Cary Joji Fukunaga for David Oyelowo's Yoruba Saxon Productions based on his family's own experience with Japanese incarceration. As a director, he is in post on "Serenity," an intimate 16mm documentary about a multi-generational family in the Pacific Northwest. "Anima," starring Sydney Chandler and Takehiro Hira, is Brian's narrative feature film debut.

long_description: As a career-defining chapter propels him into global stardom, musician Noah Kahan stands at a crossroads. In the wake of the breakout success of Stick Season—an album born from the quiet of rural Vermont and embraced around the world—Noah begins work on his follow-up album while facing the mounting pressure of what comes next. Over a whirlwind year of sold-out tours and unprecedented acclaim, he returns to his Vermont roots and family. Buoyed by his uncanny wit, he searches for a sense of home and creative inspiration as he confronts the deeply personal struggles that have left him out of sync with himself.

name: #WhileBlack

contributors.name: Sidney Fussell
contributors.details: Sidney Fussell is a Brooklyn-based filmmaker and journalist, Co-Director of #WhileBlack. A former senior reporter at WIRED and technology reporter for The Atlantic, his work has appeared in Rolling Stone, The Guardian, and EBONY. He’s been featured on NPR, BBC, and Al Jazeera, and spoken at Mozilla and NYU’s Journalism & AI panel.

contributors.name: Jennifer Holness
contributors.details: Jennifer Holness is an award-winning writer, producer, and director, and Co-Director of #WhileBlack. The first Black woman in Canada to win a CSA for writing, she was named 2021 Indiescreen Producer of the Year and received the 2022 WIFT Award of Creative Excellence. She’s also a founding member of the Black Screen Office.

long_description: #WhileBlack is an urgent documentary that centers on one of the most viral videos of our time: George Floyd’s murder, seen 1.4 billion times in 12 days, sparking protests in over 2,000 cities worldwide. With exclusive access to Darnella Frazier and others like  Diamond Reynolds, who livestreamed Philando Castile’s killing, the film reveals how social platforms and corporations profit from viral Black trauma, while survivors endure lasting psychological and physical danger. #WhileBlack is a powerful meditation on modern witnessing, exposing the human cost of viral footage while asking urgent questions about race, technology, and accountability.

long_description: Julia and Charlie, a volatile couple in Portland, Oregon, are at a loss for how to repair their broken relationship. Julia, an ambitious game designer, and Charlie, a struggling musician working in sound design to pay the bills, are pushed by Julia's friend into attending a couples-therapy seminar run by twin healers, the Tillies, who claim to fix relationships through energy work. The session triggers a karmic universal system that makes the state of their relationship affect the world around them. With earthquakes, the stock market, and entire nations at risk, Charlie and Julia must confront whether their love can survive amidst so much destruction.

She has had a distinguished career holding leadership positions as a Chief Operations Officer, Chief Product Officer, and Chief Sales Officer working for Amazon Web Services and IBM. She is a pioneer and at the forefront of AI and other leading-edge technology driving innovation, product development, and capturing new sales markets. Sandy has led the business development efforts at Fortune 100 companies that changed the business landscape and resulted in adding billions of dollars to her employers’ bottom line.

name: Beyond Checkpoints: Immunotherapy’s Next Act

contributors.company: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center
contributors.name: Dr. Padmanee Sharma, PhD, MD
contributors.title: Professor, Department Of Genitourinary Medical Oncology, Division Of Cancer Medicine

contributors.company: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center
contributors.name: Dr. James Allison, PhD
contributors.title: Regental Chair Of Immunology And Director Of The Allison Institute
contributors.details: James P. Allison, Ph.D., the 2018 Nobel Laureate for Physiology or Medicine, has spent a distinguished career studying the regulation of T cell responses and pioneering new strategies for cancer immunotherapy. He is Regental Professor and Chair of Immunology, Executive Director of the Immunotherapy Platform and Director of the James P. Allison Institute at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Work in his lab led to the development of ipilimumab, the first immune checkpoint blockade therapy approved by the FDA, which launched the field of cancer immunotherapy and has since been approved to treat multiple cancer types. Through the Allison Institute, he seeks to improve the use of immunotherapies and identify new targets to unleash the immune system to eradicate cancer.

contributors.name: Sharon Belvin
contributors.title: Board Certified Health And Wellness Coach
contributors.details: Sharon Belvin is a stage 4 melanoma survivor, health and wellness educator, and motivational speaker. At the age of 22, after taking all available cancer treatments, she enrolled in a clinical trial of ipilimumab (Yervoy), a CTLA-4 checkpoint inhibitor. After treatment one year later, she was declared cancer free. Continuing to pursue her career in health and wellness, Belvin’s previous experience includes serving as a Health Educator/Wellness Coach at University of Pittsburgh Medical Center where she guided education on wellness for six hospitals. She holds a Master of Education from West Virginia University.

contributors.name: Alice Park
contributors.title: Senior Health Correspondent
contributors.details: Alice Park is the senior health correspondent with TIME and author of The Stem Cell Hope, How Stem Cell Medicine Can Change Our Lives. In 2019, she co-chaired the inaugural Time 100 Health Summit. She has written cover stories on stem cells, childhood vaccinations, the health care system, heart disease, HIV, cancer immunotherapy and the gene editing technology CRISPR. Park contributed to TIME’s coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on the race to develop effective vaccines. She has appeared on numerous broadcasts including CNN, BBC America, NPR and Good Morning America, and has moderated panels at major industry conferences and events. Key topics include global health threats, aging, GLP-1 medications, women’s health, the role of technology and AI in health, among others.

description: Checkpoint inhibitors opened the door; now a new wave of immunotherapy discoveries is poised to turn more cancers into curable diseases. MD Anderson’s Nobel Laureate James Allison – inventor of the first immune checkpoint inhibitor – and immunotherapy pioneer Padmanee Sharma sit down with 21-year, stage-IV cancer survivor Sharon Belvin and veteran TIME journalist Alice Park to chart where the science goes next and what still blocks its path. Attendees will learn how immunotherapy advances are changing the cancer landscape, including technologies to watch and a candid look at obstacles ahead.

name: Mentor Session: Marisa Sechrest (Nova Sky Stories)

contributors.name: Marisa Sechrest
contributors.title: Executive Producer
contributors.details: Marisa Sechrest is an Executive Producer with Nova Sky Stories, the premiere drone entertainment company (Olympics, Super Bowl, FIFA, United Nations etc.). With over 20 years of senior executive level experience at prominent media and entertainment companies including Paramount Pictures, she has a proven track record in global development, exploitation, and financing of intellectual property across multiple mediums. A Harvard-trained entertainment attorney, she has co-produced projects garnering 3 Tony Awards and 42 Tony Nominations. She led growth initiatives at Paramount Pictures' live stage division and oversaw global brand exploitation for clients like Beyoncé and NBCUniversal at The Araca Group. Her career began as an entertainment attorney at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP, working on high-profile acquisitions and innovative entertainment transactions. A former professional ballerina, Sechrest has been a member of the Broadway League since 2006 and lectures on producing at the Commercial Theater Institute and The University of Texas, Austin.

contributors.name: Gueriel Mendes
contributors.title: Entertainment Attorney
contributors.details: Gueriel is a bilingual attorney specializing in long-term business strategy for artists and creatives across the U.S. and Latin America. His practice at NTSS Law focuses on complex music transactions, including recording, publishing, touring, and catalog deals for top-tier talent.Before joining NTSS, Gueriel worked at RIMAS Music, where he handled matters for major Latin artists such as Bad Bunny, Eladio Carrión, and Arcángel. At NTSS, he continues to advise prominent talent including Nicky Jam, Alleh, The Rude Boyz, Súbelo Neo, and Joaquina, among others.In collaboration with partners Nicolás Tevez and Sophia Sofferman, he leads key negotiations and ensures that artists are creatively and strategically protected. Grounded in the values of the firm, Gueriel brings a human-centered approach to his advocacy, committed to empowering clients and shaping the future of the music industry.

name: Mentor Session: Alberto Chapa (Ableton)

contributors.name: Alberto Chapa
contributors.title: Business Development
contributors.details: Alberto Chapa is a music producer, educator, and business development strategist specializing in artist growth and music technology.At Ableton, Alberto collaborates with artists, educators, and industry partners to grow creative communities and expand access to music technology. As an Ableton Certified Trainer, he also provides hands-on coaching to musicians, educators and producers, helping them refine their workflow and creative process.Beyond his role at Ableton, Alberto is the founder of Musical Guest, a company specializing in artist development and performance engineering. He has collaborated with artists across genres including Andre 3000, Imagine Dragons, LP Giobbi, Caroline Rose, Papa Roach, Polyphia, and DIIV; helping them translate their creative vision into compelling performances.In addition to his work with artists, Alberto works with educational organizations and nonprofits, helping them integrate music technology into their programs. His experience spans from designing music curricula to equipping schools and community spaces with the tools and knowledge needed to foster creative expression. Whether working with individuals, institutions, or brands, Alberto bridges creativity and technology, equipping artists, brands and educators with the tools and strategies to innovate and thrive.

name: Publicity and Marketing Mentor Session: Lee Meltzer (Lee Meltzer Consulting)

contributors.name: Lee Meltzer
contributors.title: Founder
contributors.details: Lee Meltzer is an award-winning publicity and marketing executive known for high-impact campaigns across film, television, live events, sports, and consumer brands. As founder of Lee Meltzer Consulting, he leads strategic, boutique-style initiatives with the creative reach of a top-tier agency. With over a decade of experience, he drives breakthrough coverage across premier outlets and major festivals including Sundance, SXSW, Tribeca, TIFF, SDCC, and NYCC.A trusted advisor to filmmakers, studios, distributors, executives, and talent, Lee is known for identifying bold opportunities and elevating both projects and careers. His work spans actors, directors, producers, athletes, authors, and podcasters.He serves on advisory boards for the Annapolis Film Festival, E2AC, SXSW, and the San Quentin Film Festival, and sits on the Board of Directors for the Mystic Film Institute. He has spoken at SCAD, NYU, UGA, Syracuse, FIT, Florida, and festivals including The Gotham and Ebertfest.

contributors.name: David Magdael
contributors.title: President/Ceo
contributors.details: With over two decades in PR/marketing for award winning documentaries, films and media content, David Magdael and his company DAVID MAGDAEL & ASSOCIATES have become an important leader in the field. A recent Peabody Award Winner, he leads Oscar/awards campaigns, theatrical releases, festival launches, and streaming/broadcast premieres. Magdael is one of the top media strategists and is a longtime AMPAS member and a mentor at the Sundance Institute Producers Lab, Global Media Makers, Film Independent, Berlinale EFM, SF FILM, IDFA, Tribeca and more. He is a member of the Board of Advisors for SXSW Film & TV Festival.He is one of the founders of Asian Pacific Filmmakers Experience (APFE) since 2002 creating events for AAPI filmmakers at Sundance, Tribeca, Toronto, LA Asian, SXSW and CAAM Film Festivals.   Films include: 2000 METERS TO ANDRIIVKA; COME SEE ME IN THE GOOD LIGHT; PUR YOUR SOUL ON YOUR HAND AND WALK; THE LAST REPAIR SHOP; THE EYES OF GHANA; 20 DAYS IN MARIUPOL; FOR SAMA; and more.

name: Round Table: Sales, Acquisitions, and Distribution: Bethiael Alemayoh, Bill Vergos, and Carylanna Taylor

contributors.name: Bethiael Alemayoh
contributors.title: Director of Content and Distribution
contributors.details: Bethiael Alemayoh is an independent filmmaker who guides independent filmmakers through the public media distribution pipeline. In her role as the Director of Content & Distribution at Austin PBS, she oversees the “Austin PBS Presents” slate, facilitating the national distribution of local films & television projects. Her mission is to demystify the distribution process for filmmakers by educating them on the public media model and empowering them to make the best choices for their projects, with strong consideration to career sustainability. Since joining Austin PBS, she's distributed over 30 projects including: City of Songs, How Are We Today, Price of Paradise, and more.Bethiael also oversaw the launch of Austin PBS's inaugural filmmaker grant programs in 2025: the Finishing Funds grant for existing documentaries and the Digital Originals Grant for new and fresh local web series.As a narrative filmmaker her own work has screened nationally and internationally with festivals and organizations, such as: SXSW, BlackStar Film Festival, Palm Springs International Film Festival, The Bullock Texas State History Museum, and more. Her work has received support from Indie Memphis and the Sundance Institute.

contributors.name: Carylanna Taylor
contributors.title: Director of Sales and Acquisitions
contributors.details: Carylanna Taylor is a filmmaker, anthropologist, and Director of Sales and Acquisitions at The Film Sales Company, where she helps independent films reach global audiences. She holds an M.F.A. in Producing from the American Film Institute Conservatory and a Ph.D. in Applied Cultural Anthropology from the University of South Florida. Carylanna has worked in development with Oscar-winning production companies and produced both documentary and narrative shorts and features. As co-founder of First Encounter Productions, she produced the features Anya (2019) and Painting the Way to the Moon (2015), blending storytelling with social and scientific inquiry. Before filmmaking, she conducted research and taught in Latin America on migration, environment, and sustainable development, earning awards from Fulbright and the National Science Foundation. She continues to merge her anthropological lens with film, developing new projects on mental health and migration.

contributors.name: Bill Vergos
contributors.title: Head of Digital Film Distribution
contributors.details: Bill Vergos is the Head of Digital Film Distribution at Magenta Light Studios, overseeing digital release strategy and platform partnerships as the company expands its presence in the global streaming and independent film space. Prior to Magenta Light, he spent 15 years at Freestyle Digital Media, helping build the division into one of North America’s leading independent distribution labels and releasing more than 700 titles across TVOD, SVOD, AVOD, FAST, and theatrical platforms.Vergos has a strong track record with SXSW alumni, acquiring and releasing several festival titles, including A Bad Idea Gone Wrong, Aberrance, Best Summer Ever, KRZYK: Losing Control, KTown Cowboys, and Served Like a Girl. Recognized by Media Play News as one of the Top Indie Film Distribution Power Players of 2024 and 2025, he is committed to supporting and empowering the next generation of independent filmmakers. Originally from Chicago, Vergos is a graduate of Emerson College’s film program.

name: Featured Session: David Pogue on Apple’s First 50 Years

contributors.name: David Pogue
contributors.title: Author
contributors.details: David Pogue is a seven-time Emmy Award winner for his stories on “CBS Sunday Morning,” a five-time TED speaker, host of 20 “NOVA” specials on PBS, and a New York Times bestselling author. He’s written about Apple for his entire career, including 13 years as a Macworld columnist, 13 more as the New York Times tech columnist, and 20 years as the #1 bestselling author of books about Macs and iPhones. He lives with his family in New York.

description: As Apple enters its second half-century, author David Pogue (“Apple: The First 50 Years”) explores the throughlines of Apple’s astonishing success: simplicity, beauty, elegant design, making the whole widget, focus on very few products, and a deep commitment to the customer experience. He’ll be joined by a special guest to share stories and insights from their decades of launching iconic products.

contributors.name: Heather Wagner-Reed
contributors.title: Founder/Ceo & Co-Founder/Director/Adjunct Professor
contributors.details: Heather Wagner Reed is the Founder and CEO of Juice Consulting - and a prominent voice and passionate advocate for the creative sector in Austin, Texas. Hailed by SPIN magazine as “Austin’s premier marketing & PR firm,” the agency works with some of the most innovative tech accelerators in the region to international government and local nonprofits - to entertainment sector greats like Gloria Gaynor and Erykah Badu. Juice also handles PR and marketing for the Space Workforce Incubator for Texas (SWIFT), where Heather is a Cofounder and Director. Named the 2025 Local Agency of the Year by the Alliance for Woman in Media, Juice’s motto is they “add vitality to your campaign” - and act as a conduit for both legacy brands and what’s next in the ATX including everything from rock stars to rocket fuel. Before starting Juice in 2007, Heather served as Senior Product Manager for 35 GRAMMY®-winning artist Beyoncé, handling her day-to-day management. Prior to moving to Texas in 2002, she lived in The Netherlands for five years and worked in international marketing. Heather is in her sixth year with Austin Community College as an Adjunct Professor teaching “Marketing and PR for Creatives.”

She is an Assistant Professor of Communications at Springfield College and holds a part-time Faculty, Research, and Consultant position at New York University. Dr. Fadia is a published author and has served on numerous DEIBS committees in a variety of universities and organizations. Her research areas are DEIBS, and she has created a system of organizational inclusion called the Inclusive Business Model Canvas (IBMC) that aids in building an inclusive foundational structure.

contributors.name: Tammy Lynn Gilmore
contributors.title: Executive Producer
contributors.details:
Tammy Lynn Gilmore is a community builder, live events producer, creator of the SXSW community grant program and Executive Producer of the first-ever Texas Women Songwriters Festival in Lockhart, Texas. She has programmed innovation Summits with Singularity University partners in countries from Greece to Sweden to South Africa.

She is currently the Program Lead for Canva’s annual design event called Create. She produced immersive, experiential event activations for gaming companies at DICE and GDC. She was the community lead at the location-based social app Gowalla. She executive produced a campaign launch for the UN-endorsed Digital Public Goods Alliance. She oversaw the first-ever exhibition for the 3rd International Conference on Public Health in Africa (CPHIA) led by the Africa CDC.

She sings and performs in a musical duo with her husband, Colin Gilmore. She assistant teaches a songwriting workshop at the Omega Institute of Holistic Studies. She is a voting member of the Recording Academy and has managed bands like the West Texas Exiles. She loves working on all things where art, creativity, technology, science and human rights meet.

contributors.name: Scott Coleman
contributors.title: Creative Producer
contributors.details: Scott has been described as a musical Swiss Army Knife. An experienced creative, producer, composer, songwriter, audio engineer, and DJ, his breadth of skill sets makes him a highly valued collaborator for all types of projects. He’s creative directed global campaigns for some of the world’s leading brands including American Airlines, Citi Bank, Squarespace, and composed tracks that have landed on spots with Don Julio, Abercrombie, and Dr Pepper. His music has made its way onto an Oikos superbowl spot and a rockstar-studded campaign for Workday. He was also an early pioneer of custom music for brand campaigns on TikTok, with his sounds racking up billions of views and impressions on the platform.    Currently residing in San Diego. When he isn’t cooking up some heat for The Elements, you can find him surfing, snowboarding, or hanging with his cat.

contributors.name: Malayna Ellis
contributors.title: Head of Sync + A&R
contributors.details: Malayna Ellis is Head of Sync and A&R at Butter Music and Sound, specializing in music supervision for advertising and creative sync licensing across all media. She leads Butter’s A&R-driven sync strategy, aligning music with narrative and brand objectives. Previously, Ellis worked in creative sync at Glassnote Records, supporting pitching and licensing for a roster of internationally recognized artists. She is also a freelance film music supervisor, most recently on Pretty Thing (2025), and brings a curator-led perspective informed by her background as an active DJ.

Each session will be followed up a social hour. Physical submissions will not be accepted at the door. related_sales_client.name: Discovr Radio
related_sales_client.company_bio: Discovr is an artist-focused service that lets musicians and songwriters have their music played on radio station streams, alongside broadcast programming. Artists, labels, managers, and distributors can use Discovr to upload tracks and have them inserted into radio streams – in place of ad interruptions – through faidr, a radio streaming app. Once a track has been approved, Discovr customers can monitor listener engagement and behavior through a robust analytics dashboard.

name: Designing AI for the Worst Day of Your Life

contributors.name: Thiyagu Ramasamy
contributors.title: Head of Global Public Sector
contributors.details: Thiyagu Ramasamy is head of Global Public Sector at Anthropic, an AI safety and research company working to build reliable, interpretable and steerable AI systems. Ramasamy’s experience comprises more than a decade of deep federal AI/ML expertise with proven AI safety leadership. He's deployed AI/ML in highly sensitive environments, previously spearheading the Amazon Web Services Emerging Technologies Team and architecting data analytics at Accenture Federal Services for defense, civilian and state/local agencies. He holds a MS/BE in Computer Science.

contributors.name: Mahesh Saptharishi
contributors.title: Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer
contributors.details:
Mahesh Saptharishi is executive vice president and chief technology officer of Motorola Solutions. He is responsible for the company’s global product organization, overseeing product development for critical communications, video security and command center. 

Saptharishi joined Motorola Solutions in 2018 through the acquisition of Avigilon, a video security solutions company, where he served as senior vice president and chief technology officer. Prior to Avigilon, he founded VideoIQ, a video analytics company that was acquired by Avigilon, as well as Broad Reach Security, which was later acquired by GE.

Saptharishi earned a doctoral degree in artificial intelligence from Carnegie Mellon University.

description: Would you trust AI to save your life? Join Motorola Solutions and Anthropic to explore designing AI for your worst day. Discover how rigorously boundary testing AI in life-or-death situations—where seconds save lives—reveals critical truths for AI safety. Unpack "good friction" and essential controls to prevent harmful AI, including automation bias. Learn frameworks for responsible human-AI collaboration applicable across any industry, building AI you can stake your life on.

contributors.name: Harriet Torry
contributors.title: Reporter
contributors.details: Harriet Torry is The Wall Street Journal’s economics correspondent for the Western U.S.Previously she covered the U.S. economy and Federal Reserve from the Journal's Washington, D.C., bureau. Harriet joined the Journal in Frankfurt in 2010 as a financial reporter, before moving to Berlin to cover the German government and economy during the eurozone sovereign debt crisis.

contributors.name: David Stout
contributors.title: Co-founder and CEO
contributors.details: David Stout is the co-founder and CEO of webAI, a startup pioneering private, on-device AI infrastructure for custom model creation and distributed compute. Under his leadership, webAI is valued at $2.5B and has secured key customers including ŌURA.David is an accomplished researcher and a UPenn AI Awardee, recognized for innovations in Attention Steering, Guided Attention, and Adaptive Large Infrastructure Models (LIM). He has over a decade of experience in enterprise technology, with deep expertise in building and scaling advanced AI systems.

contributors.name: Tom Hale
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Tom Hale is the CEO of ŌURA, the company behind the smart ring that has changed the way people understand and optimize their health through personalized insights and continuous biometric monitoring. While Tom has been CEO, ŌURA has reached a valuation of $5.2B and closed a $200M Series D round. Prior to joining ŌURA, Tom held executive roles at companies including Momentive (formerly SurveyMonkey), Linden Lab (creator of Second Life), and Adobe. He has 20+ years of leadership experience across product, operations, and growth. He also serves as an advisor/investor at NoiseAware and Volara and is a member of the board at Cars.com. Tom holds a B.A. from Harvard University.

description: AI adoption is growing, but cloud-based AI is hitting limits like high costs, privacy concerns, environmental damage, & latency issues. This session will explore why the next generation of AI will be specialized, expert, & local. Panelists will unpack how on-device AI can deliver improved performance, privacy, & scalability with a more sustainable infrastructure. They’ll share how local AI is changing businesses, reshaping privacy expectations, and shifting the global tech landscape - and the next steps the industry has to take to make the use of local AI widespread.

name: Money, Sex & Religion - How Design Turns Taboo to Touchpoint

contributors.name: Dominic Davis
contributors.title: Reporter
contributors.details: Dominic-Madori Davis is a senior venture capital and startup reporter at TechCrunch.

contributors.name: Shan Boodram
contributors.title: Chief Intimacy Officer
contributors.details: Shan Boodram is the Chief Intimacy Officer at Arya, the AI-enabled couples wellness platform. As a certified sexologist and AASECT-certified sex educator, Shan is one of the internet’s most sought-after voices on intimacy and relationships. Through Arya, she’s helping to remove the stigma, shame, and guesswork around kink, communication, and connection. She draws from over a decade of education and on-the-ground experience—including as a mother of two—to inform inclusive, empowering tools for modern love and sex.

contributors.name: Phylicia Koh
contributors.title: General Partner
contributors.details: Phylicia is a General Partner at Play Ventures a leading early-stage VC fund that invests globally in gaming, consumer apps and gaming-adjacent tech. Phylicia has led investments into Alter (avatar tech company acquired by Google, Arya (AI-driven couple intimacy platform), BibleChat (fastest growing AI-powered faith app, #4 US App Store). She most recently led Alinea's $10.4m Series A (personal financial investing app for Gen Z). Before joining Play as Employee #1, Phylicia spent 9 years in marketing and growth, working with the likes of Mighty Bear Games, Voice Labs, Homage, Ethnicraft Online, as well as for the Singapore Economic Development Board.

contributors.name: Anam Lakhani
contributors.title: Co-CEO
contributors.details: Anam Lakhani is the Co-Founder and Co-CEO of Alinea Invest, the Gen Z investing platform built to make wealth-building simple, social, and accessible. She oversees product and design, translating complex financial systems into beautifully intuitive tools. Alinea has attracted users by reimagining investing for a new generation - prioritizing community, values-based decision making, and long-term financial health. Anam’s background includes Wall Street internships and roles at high-growth fintech startups, giving her a rare blend of institutional knowledge and startup agility. She was named to Forbes 30 Under 30 for her role in redefining how young people think about money and investing.

description: Sex, money, and religion are no longer taboo—they’re trending. This panel explores how behavioral UX, gamification, and human-centered design can destigmatize what used to be off-limits. From intimacy apps to investing platforms, discover how intentional design is helping users navigate vulnerable moments with confidence. Hear from sex educator Shan Boodram, Alinea’s Gen Z fintech founder Anam Lakhani, Bloomberg’s Riley Griffin, and Play Ventures’ Phylicia Koh—one of few female investors in gaming VC—on how intentional UX is turning discomfort into discovery.
long_description: Sex, money, and religion are no longer taboo—they’re trending. This panel explores how behavioral UX, gamification, and human-centered design can destigmatize what used to be off-limits. From intimacy apps to investing platforms, discover how intentional design is helping users navigate vulnerable moments with confidence. Hear from sex educator Shan Boodram, Alinea’s Gen Z fintech founder Anam Lakhani, Bloomberg’s Riley Griffin, and Play Ventures’ Phylicia Koh—one of few female investors in gaming VC—on how intentional UX is turning discomfort into discovery.
sort: MONEY, SEX & RELIGION - HOW DESIGN TURNS TABOO TO TOUCHPOINT
